To satisfy his continually growing number of customers, he decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso four months ago and is on his first individual loan. With this loan, he plans to buy 4 armoires, 4 beds, 2 bookshelves, etc. He does his buying on trips to Côte d’Ivoire and to Togo. The goods are sold by special order.

With this loan, he envisions realizing an average monthly profit of 20,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to augment his working capital, to help cover family expenses, and to repay the loan interest.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy furniture (dressers, beds, buffets, bookshelves, etc.)

loans.name: Mumtaz M. Niaz Group

texts.en:
Mumtaz Baji is a 38-year-old married lady and has been a citizen of a city named Pakpattan, Pakistan for the past 20 years. Her husband, M. N., runs a small hotel in the community where he sells Punjabi food. Pakistani people are fond of Punjabi food. Mumtaz Baji helps him by cooking the Punjabi foods (daal chawal, dahi bhalas and samosas). She successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy material (lentils, cooking oil and spices) to expand her husband’s food selling business.

She is a group leader of some more women of her locality. Allah Rakhi Baji and Rehana Kosar Baji each want a loan to buy a donkey cart for hauling. Ashran Baji and Shamim Akhtar Baji each want a loan to buy livestock (goats) to resell. Naseem Baji wants a loan to buy cold drinks for her cold corner.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material for food business

loans.name: Seybou

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Seybou Diabaté a 29 ans et vit avec ses 5 enfants et son épouse à Sanoubougou II, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Diabaté après avoir mener plusieurs activités sans succès, s’est initié au commerce d’articles divers. Il dispose d’une quincaillerie à la gare routière de Sikasso. Il s’occupe de cette activité il y a environ cinq ans. Il est beaucoup sollicitté pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant dix mois. Il  est à son premier prêt individuel et compte l’utiliser pour acheter,  10 boîtes de colle, 15 cartons baquette, 15 paquets de peinture, 50 mètres de file, 5 pelles, 5 piques, des talosses, etc . Il s’approvisionne auprès des commerçants grossistes à Bamako(capitale du Mali) avant de les revendre en détail à une clientèle composée généralement d’entrepreneurs, de constructeurs de maison, de maçons, etc.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et rembourser les intérêts du prêt.
texts.en:
Mr. Seybou Diabaté is 29 years old and lives with his wife and 5 children in Sanoubougou II, one of the populous districts in the city of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having run several business activities without success, Mr. Diabaté began a business selling various hardware items. He runs a hardware store at the Sikasso bus station. He has been working in this business for about five years. He is much sought-after due to the quality of his products. To satisfy his increasingly growing clientele, he has been working with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso for about ten months. He is seeking his first individual loan and intends to use it to buy 10 cans of glue, 15 boxes of pliers, 15 packs of paint, 50 metres of thread, 5 shovels, 5 awls, etc. He supplies himself from wholesalers in Bamako (the capital of Mali) and then re-sells at retail to a clientele composed generally of entrepreneurs, house-builders, masons, etc. With this loan, he foresees realizing a monthly profit of 100,000 FCFA, which will be used mainly to increase his business, contribute to his family's expenses, and repay the loan.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy glue, pliers, paint, thread, shovels, awls, and other hardware items

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela A. O. recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya. As a CHW member, she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illness. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

Pamela is 40 years old, married, with four children. She lives in Nanga village, outside of Kisumu. Pamela has two businesses that provide income for herself and her family – a tailoring business and a vegetable stall. Pamela farms her own vegetables to sell, mainly sukuma wiki (kale), tomatoes, and maize. In her tailoring business, she sells dresses for ladies, school uniforms, and also repairs clothes. She gets her materials from Kibuye Market in town.

Pamela is a Form 1 school dropout who used to make chapatti (local flat bread) to sell to her neighbors; she was also engaged in the illegal activity of brewing changa, a strong alcoholic brew. She decided to stop both of these activities and buy a sewing machine in 2004.

Pamela has applied for a loan of approximately $150 USD, which she will use to purchase dressmaking materials and farming supplies.

loans.use: To purchase dressmaking materials and farming supplies

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice O. recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya. As a CHW member, she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illness. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

Eunice is 29 years old, married, and has four children who are all currently in school. She lives in the Nyalenda area of Kisumu. Eunice has a vegetable and fruit business; she sells from a stall in her neighborhood. A Form II school dropout (when she was about 15 years old), Eunice used to sell used clothing in Kibuye market in Kisumu. After giving birth to a child, Eunice returned to her space in the market to find that it had been taken over. She decided then, in 2002, to start a fruit and vegetable stand. There she sells tomatoes, sukuma wiki (kale), cabbage, and fruit.

Eunice has applied for a loan from K-MET of approximately $150 USD. She will use this money to purchase more vegetables and to add charcoal to her inventory.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables and add charcoal to her inventory

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily O. recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya. As a CHW member, she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illness. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

Emily is 30 years old, married, and has three children who are all currently in school. She lives in the Nyalenda area of Kisumu. Emily works in food sales, owning a small shop that sells foodstuffs. She began this business because it is fast moving and she makes quick sales. Educated at a college level (Science Lab and Technology), Emily used to work at a salon. She decided this year to open her own business.

Emily has applied for her first loan from K-MET, for approximately $150 USD. She will use this money to enlarge her business by purchasing new inventory and expanding her range of foodstuffs.

loans.use: Buying more food stuff

loans.name: Emmanuel Group

texts.en:
Jeimy L. and Yasmel P. are group coordinators for the Enmanuel Bank of Hope, from Villa Mella. This area is located on the northern outskirts of Santo Domingo. Jeimy´s group is on their third loan cycle and Yasmel´s group is on its first.

Jeimy has 3 children, ages 11, 9 and 2. She sells shoes from a catalog. She sells from her own home and also visits her clients to show them the catalog so they can place their orders. The shoes she sells the most are women´s. She will use this loan to purchase the shoes her clients have ordered from her. She says her biggest challenge is to get her customers to pay her on time. She dreams of one day renting a space where she can have her own store and sell not only shoes, but also clothes and accessories.

Yasmel has a one-year-old daughter. She sells clothes for all ages. The highest demand she gets is for women´s clothing. She buys her merchandise by bundles in order to buy a larger amount at a much smaller price. She sells from home, where her customers visit her. Her dream is to one day have her own store in Avenida Duarte in Santo Domingo (the largest commercial strip in the city).

On behalf of Esperanza International, thank you for supporting these entrepreneurs!

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for last order placed

loans.name: Josinta

texts.en:
Josinta A. O. recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya, where she will be trained by K-MET to begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illness. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour, a vitamin-enriched flour produced by K-MET, to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

Josinta, who lives in the Nyamasaria district of Kisumu, is 36 years old, married, and has four children; she also cares for three orphans. She has a business at the Molem Market selling fresh fish caught in Lake Victoria, upon whose banks the town of Kisumu is situated. She normally buys the fish straight from vendors at the lakeside, but at times will purchase stock from middlemen in town.

Josinta has applied for a loan of $325 from K-MET for both the purchase of additional fish and the upkeep of her business.

loans.use: To purchase fish.

loans.name: Johari

texts.en: Johari M. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur and married woman with five children. Two twins are in kindergarten and two children are in primary school. Joha runs a business of selling charcoal at Vituka ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases the charcoal directly from the producers wholesale and sells it retail to customers at Vituka. In each trip, she carries seventy charcoal bags, and she makes two trips per month. Charcoal is a main source of power in most developing countries in Africa due to the instability and high price of electricity. She is requesting a loan of Tshs 1,400,000 to purchase more charcoal bags to meet customer demand.

loans.use: To buy more stock (charcoal)

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en:
Roseline A. recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya.

As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will visit members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care. 

Roseline is a 24 years old, married, and a mother of two. One of her children is in school, while the second one is too young to attend school. She and her family live in the Nyalenda area of Kisumu. 

Roseline has a small business selling new shoes for ladies. She began her business in 2008 and gets her stock of shoes from Busia, Kenya (on the border of Uganda) and from Uganda.  For two years prior, she used to sell second-hand clothes, but changed her business due to the high level of competition and lack of market for the products. 

Roseline has applied for a loan of approximately $275 USD. She will use the loan money to buy shoes in bulk in order to grow her business.

loans.use: To purchase shoes in bulk

loans.name: Ally

texts.en: Ally K. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur and married man. He runs a business of selling charcoal at Kisiwan ward in Dar es Salaam. He purchases charcoal bags directly from the producers wholesale and sells it retail to customers from Vituka. K. has been running the business for three years. The income generated is used to meet his family's daily demands and to pay his children's school fees. He is requesting a loan of Tshs 600,000 to increase his purchases of charcoal bags.

loans.use: To buy more stock (charcoal)

loans.name: Milicent

texts.en:
Milicent O. recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya.

As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will visit members of her community who are sick with a variety of illness. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care. 

Milicent is 27 years old, married, and mother of two children, both of whom are currently in school. 

Milicent sells second hand ladies clothing in her home district in the Nyalenda area of Kisumu. She purchases her stock from Kibuye market in town. Milicent had previously been in college and then ran a catering business from 2004 – 2005. She started her current business in 2007 when she decided that she wanted to raise money to help her children and family. 

Milicent has recently applied for a loan of approximately $400 USD. She will use the loan money to purchase more used clothing in order to expand her stock.

loans.use: To purchase used clothing

loans.name: Tito Francisco

texts.en:
Tito Francisco is a young business owner who is very dedicated to his clients. He has a business where he makes and sells fast food (mostly pizza), and his business has done very well. He has always been a hard worker and when he was very young learned how to make bread at a bakery, an experience that has allowed him to now have his own business. 

Tito has two daughters, ages 3 and 5, and together with the support of his wife his family has been able to continue moving forward. Now, Tito needs capital to purchase a professional oven. With this oven he will be able to expand his business and increase his sales. He wants to give his wife and daughters a better life.


***********************************************************

Tito Francisco es un joven comerciante muy dedicado a sus clientes, actualmente tiene un negocio de elaboración y venta de comida rápida (pizza) en el cual le ha ido muy bien.  Gracias a Dios durante su niñez aprendió a ser muy trabajador, y desde muy pequeño aprendió a hacer pan en una panadería, y por eso él ahora tiene su propio negocio.  Tito es padre de familia, tiene dos niñas de 3 y 5 años de edad, y con la ayuda de su esposa han podido salir juntos adelante.  Ahora él tiene la necesidad de contar con capital para comprar un horno profesional, de esta manera ampliar su negocio y poder incrementar sus ventas.  El desea darles una mejor vida a su esposa e hijas.

loans.use: To buy a professional oven for his pizza store

loans.name: Sisti

texts.en: Sisti P. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur and married man. His business is a shop. He runs the business at Buguruni ward in Dar es Salaam. He sells a variety of items, including cereal crop products such as maize flour, wheat flour, ground nuts, cashew nuts, and sugar. Business items are purchased directly from the producers and from Kariakoo city market. He is requesting a loan of Tshs 600,000 to boost up the business.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for his shop

loans.name: Zulfa

texts.en: Zulfa A. is a married Tanzanian woman with three school children. She runs a business selling traditional clothes (Vitenge and Khanga) at Bugurun ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases the items from Mnazi mmoja traditional wholesale shops and Kariakoo city market center. She has been in the business for four years. She is requesting a loan of Tshs 600,000 to buy more business items to meet her customers' demand.

loans.use: To buy more business items

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela A. R. recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya.

As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will visit members of her community who are sick with a variety of illness. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care. 

Pamela is 20 years old, unmarried, and has no children. She lives in the Nyalenda district of Kisumu. 

Pamela started a tailoring business in the Nyalenda district in 2007. Prior to that, she attended dressmaking training school from 2004 to 2006. She chose to start this business to enable herself to be independent and to earn an income. Pamela makes African attire and local church attire. She gets her materials from Busia, a town on the border of Uganda (about a 5 hour bus ride from Kisumu). 

Pamela has applied for her first loan of $275 USD from K-MET.  She will use the loan money to purchase tailoring materials in bulk from Busia. By buying in bulk instead of small amounts, this will reduce her travel time and save her money.

loans.use: To purchase dressmaking materials in bulk

loans.name: Ayao André

texts.fr: Monsieur A. Ayao andré est un menusier, il habite le quartier d’adidogomé, il est spécialisé dans la fabrication des meubles qu’il revend après, il dispose d’un atelier qu’il a appelé menuserie ELOLO. Il n’a jamais obtenu de prêt de wages et sollicite son premier c r édit d’un montant de 300000F pour acheter des planches. Il fait ce commerce depuis 1988. Il est un homme marié avec deux enfants à sa charge.
texts.en:
Mr. Ayao André A. is a cabinet maker and lives in the Adidogomé district. He specializes in making furniture, which he then sells. He has a workshop that he calls “Menuserie ELOLO”. He has never been the recipient of a WAGES loan and is requesting his first loan in the amount of 30,000 francs CFA for buying planks. Mr. A. has been in this business since 1988. He is a married man with two children to support.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy lumber

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane A. O. recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya.

As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will visit members of her community who are sick with a variety of illness. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care. 

Jane is 40 years old, married, and has five children. Four of her children are currently attending school. Her family lives in the Nyalenda district of Kisumu.

In 1990, Jane started a business selling mandazi (similar to doughnuts), chapatti (a soft flat bread), and vegetables. The business is located in Nyalenda. Initially, the business did not require a large amount of capital and the products sold quickly. Jane has applied for a loan of $150 USD in order to buy products to make mandazi and chapatti in bulk.

loans.use: To purchase baking ingredients

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en: Janeth Alfan runs a café at Buguruni ward. She is a micro entrepreneur, Tanzanian married woman. Business income generated is used to meet her daily family demand and paying school fees and partly for capitalization. She managed to buy a building site in Dar es Salaam. She has been in the business for four years. She is requesting a loan of Tshs 1,000,000 to boost up her business.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Mujeres En Accion Group

texts.en:
There are three groups of women participating in a shared loan entitled Bank of Hope. All the members live in Villa Mella, on the northern outskirts of Santo Domingo. The group coordinators are Carmen M., Justa H., and Rosa S.. 

Justa has four children; ages 26, 23, 19 and 17. Her children do not live with her anymore, but three of her grand-children do.  She sells personal care products and also runs a fried food stand. She says her peak business days are weekends. She has a volunteer helper on some mornings when she is not at the house. Justa is seeking a loan to make repairs on her business and buy new merchandise.  

Justa´s favorite activity is cooking and she says people really like her food. One day, she dreams of having her own restaurant where she can serve her clients with all kinds of food, including her favorites desserts. 

Carmen has a two year old daughter. Four months ago, Carmen opened a colmado which is a small grocery store.   She recognizes her job is very demanding job because she is required to be at the store all the time. However, she also thinks this brings her great satisfaction. “It means I´m always there for my customers, so I´m satisfied by serving them” she says.  She dreams of one day having a large grocery store where her customers can find anything they might need. She will use the full amount of her loan to purchase merchandise to restock her business.

Rosa has four children who are all grown up. She runs a business managing rental houses. She will use her loan to make repairs on the houses she shows for rent. She hopes one day to be a formal real estate agent and to be able to offer her customers houses for rent in excellent conditions. 

Thank you for supporting these entrepreneurs!

loans.use: To purchase new merchandise

loans.name: Julia Liliana

texts.en:
Julia Liliana is an extremely hard-working woman who lives in a very poor area just outside Guatemala City. She is always busy sewing clothes (her first businesses) and has recently graduated from a professional pastry course specializing in cake preparation (her second business). 

Her children have helped her greatly to succeed. She currently has her sewing business, and it has done very well. The products are of good quality, and her clients are demanding more products. Julia Liliana needs a loan to increase her products and to better meet the needs of her customers. 

This is her second loan with Kiva. She will use part of this loan to buy more fabric and sewing necessities, and part of the loan to invest in the bakery and to buy the many things she needs for this business. She says that all of this will allow her to continue moving forward and to be a better person every day.

****************************************

Julia Liliana es una mujer muy trabajadora quien vive en una communidad muy pobre fuera de la Capital del Pais. Se ha dedicado a la costura de ropa  (su primer negocio) y se ha graduado recientemente de repostería profesional de elaboración de pasteles (su segundo negocio) .  

Sus hijos la han ayudado mucho a que ella se supere.  Ella actualmente tiene su negocio de costura y le ha ido muy bien, ya que sus productos son de buena calidad, y sus clientes le han propuesto que agrande sus negocios, por eso ella necesita de un préstamo para aumentar sus productos y poder atender mejor a sus clientes.

Este préstamo es su segundo prestamo de Kiva. Con el préstamo que solicita, ella comprará  mas telas y mobiliario, también aprovechará  para invertir en la repostería, donde compraría muchas cosas que se necesitan para ello.  Con todo eso ella dice que puede salir adelante, y ser una mejor persona cada día.

loans.use: Bulk fabric and sewing materials

loans.name: Ayéné

texts.fr: Cette dame habite le quartier de novissi à lomé, elle  a pour activité génératrice de revenu le commerce des marmites qu’elle exerce depuis 1998, elle fait son commerce depuis 1998, son stock étant épuisé, elle sollicite son premier crédit d’un montant de 500000F pour pouvoir se réapprovisionner. Elle est mariée et a 03 enfants.
texts.en:
This is a woman who lives in the Novissi district in Lomé. She works to earn an income doing commerce in pots and pans, something she has been doing since 1998. Since her inventory is exhausted, she is requesting her first loan in the amount of 50,000 francs CFA for acquiring supplies. She is married and has three children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pots and pans

loans.name: Safia Group

texts.en:
Safia baji is a 39-year-old married lady and has resided in a city called Pakpattan, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Her husband's name is M. N. H. and he is an electrician by profession. He is efficient in his work. Mostly people call him for repairing their items.

Safia baji is the mother of four kids: three sons and one daughter. Her eldest son works in a factory. The others are getting an education from a school in the neighborhood. Safia baji is a housewife but she sews clothes also to help her husband to meet their expenses. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy electrician's tools for her husband.

She is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Arshan baji and Mumtaz baji each want a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Sheema baji wants a loan to buy animals (goats) for her animal-selling business. Zulaikhan baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for transport. Another Sheema baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Khalida Parveen baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruit for her fruit-selling business. This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy repair tools

loans.name: Riaz M. Akhtar Bhatti Group
loans.use: To buy electric items for her husband's business.

loans.name: Essodina

texts.fr: Ce monsieur a pour activité la réparation de portables de même que les accessoires téléphoniques qui y vont avec, il fait ce commerce depuis 2006 et a son propre atelier qu’il a appelé MANOU Mobile, actuellement le commerce de partables et accessoires marche bien à lomé et c’est pour répondre à la demande que ce monsieur demande à wages un crédit de 400000F pour acheter des accessoires de portables. Il est marié et a 02 enfants
texts.en:
This gentleman does work that involves repairing mobile phones, as well as phone accessories that go with them. He has been in this business since 2006 and has his own workshop he calls “MANOU Mobile”. His business is currently doing well in Lomé. And to meet the demand, he is asking WAGES for a loan of 40,000 francs CFA to buy mobile phone accessories. He is married and has two children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cell phone accessories

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester A. L. recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya.

As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illness. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care. 

Ester is 27 years old, married, and has two children, one of whom is currently attending school. She lives with her family in the Nyalenda area of Kisumu.

Ester has a business selling used clothing in Nyalenda. She began hawking them in 2006 after changing businesses from selling vegetables.

She likes the fact that hawking gives her unlimited selling space and that she is not restricted to one area of town. She sells men’s and women’s clothing, which she buys from Uganda and sometimes from the Kibuye Market in town.

Ester has applied for a loan of approximately $150 USD. She plans to use the loan to purchase clothing in bulk.

loans.use: To purchase clothing in bulk

loans.name: Hajra M. Ameen Group

texts.en:
Hajra baji is a 41 years old married lady and has been a citizen of the city of Pakpattan, Pakistan for the past 30 years. Her husband, M. A., has a chicken selling business. Hajra baji also helps him with his business. She packs the chickens in a web mesh for selling. She has successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for another loan to buy more chickens to expand her husband’s business. 

She is a loan group leader of several women of her locality. Bushra baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her clothes selling business. Zarina baji wants a loan to buy wooden beams for her window shutter business. Ameeran baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Zubaida baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Shamim akhtar baji wants a loan to buy fertilizer to resell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy chickens for resale

loans.name: Peres

texts.en:
Peres A. recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya.

As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illness. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care. 

Peres is a 50 year old woman, married, and has six children. She lives with her family in the village of Dunga, on the outskirts of Kisumu. 

Peres owns a fishing business. She is the owner of a boat and employs fishermen to fish for Tilapia, Nile Perch, and Mud Fish in Lake Victoria. Peres then sells both fresh and dried fish in Dunga. She has had this business since 1979.

Peres has applied for a loan of approximately $150 USD. She will use this money to purchase new fishing nets.

loans.use: To purchase new fishing nets

loans.name: Meena M. Gulzar Group

texts.en:
Meena baji is a 56 years old lady. She has been a citizen of the city of Pakpattan, Pakistan for the past 30 years. Her husband, M. G., is a farmer by profession. Meena baji is the mother of four children: two sons and two daughters. Her elder son is a driver and drives a tractor in the fields. The next oldest son is involved in a milk selling business. Her daughters are single and do household work and taking care of the family. Meena baji belongs to a family of farmers, so she spends most of her time in the fields growing several types of crops. She successfully repaid her first two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy another buffalo for her second son so that he will be able to earn good income from his milk selling business. 

She is a loan group leader of some of the women in her locality. Razia baji wants a loan to buy chickens to sell. Manzooran baji wants a loan to buy electric supplies (electric wires, neon lights and switches) for her electric shop. Sugran baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her fruit selling business. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy vegetables for her vegetable selling business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo for a milk selling business

loans.name: Edga

texts.es: Edga tiene 44 años, vive con su hijo en su casa propia. Se dedica al transporte desde hace 15 años, su padre tiene una gran flota de carros que ofrecen el servicio de transporte interprovincial y ella fue durante todos estos años el brazo derecho de su padre. Algunos años atrás se independiza y con sus ahorros adquiere un autobús, ahora es la cobradora de pasajes de su propia unidad móvil. El trabajo que realiza lo hace durante todo el día, desde las primeras horas de la mañana hasta altas horas de la noche. Edga tiene muchos deseos de seguir adelante para mejorar la economía de su hogar. En el futuro quiere tener otra movilidad que le permita obtener mayores ganancias. Esta es la primera vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP, por lo que se ha comprometido a trabajar de manera responsable en su banco comunal. El dinero que solicita se invertirá en la reparación y mantenimiento de su autobús, que es su indispensable herramienta de trabajo.
texts.en:
Edga is 44 years old, and lives with her son in her own home. She has dedicated herself to transportation for the past 15 years. Her father owns a large auto fleet that offers transportation services between provinces and during all these years she was the right hand of her father. Some years back she became independent and with her savings acquired a bus, now she is the ticket collector of her own mobile unit. The work that she carries out takes place all day long, from the early hours of the morning until the late hours of the night. Edga has many wishes to continue moving forward to improve the income of her household. In the future she hopes to acquire another mobile unit that will allow her to obtain higher earnings. This is the first time that she has requested a loan with MFP, for which she has committed herself to working in a responsible manner in her communal bank. The money that she has requested will be invested in the repair and maintenance of her bus, which is her indispensable work tool.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair and maintenance of her bus.

loans.name: Darling

texts.en:
Darling A. recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya.

As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

Darling is 21 years old, married, and has 4 children, 2 of whom are currently in school. She lives with her family in the Nyalenda area of Kisumu.

Darling has been selling used clothing in her Nyalenda neighborhood since 2005. She is a primary school dropout who was initially working in a hotel in the town of Rongo. When she moved to Kisumu she decided to start selling used clothes because it is a beneficial business that enables her to make large profits. She sells ladies' and children’s dresses. Darling purchases her inventory from Kibuye Market in Kisumu.

She has requested her first loan from K-MET – a loan of approximately $150. Darling will use the money to buy a larger stock of clothing.

loans.use: To purchase used clothing

loans.name: Nora

texts.es: Nora tiene 44 años, vive con su esposo y sus 2 hijos en su propia casa. El negocio de Nora es la venta de comida, su puesto de ventas está ubicado en el paradero de una empresa de transportes y junto a una carretera muy transitada, lo que garantiza entradas seguras para ella. Cada día realiza el esfuerzo de levantarse en horas de la madrugada para preparar los alimentos, ya que vende desayunos y almuerzos a sus más exigentes clientes que en su mayoría son conductores de los vehículos que pertenecen a esa empresa de transportes. La comida que Nora hace es deliciosa y de buena la calidad, por lo que después de 20 años de haberse generado el sustento con este negocio, desea mejorarlo e incrementar las opciones de comidas y bebidas para sus clientes. Es la primera vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP, y está deseosa de emprender un trabajo solidario con todos los integrantes de su banco comunal. Con el dinero que está solicitando se implementará con lo necesario para vender jugos de fruta, comprará principalmente una licuadora, una máquina para exprimir y una extractora, con el resto de dinero adquirirá las frutas necesarias para emprender este nuevo reto.
texts.en:
Nora is 44 years old and lives with her husband and two children in their own home. Nora sells meals for a living. Her stand is located near a commuter stop and a busy roadway, which guarantees her a secure income. Every day she makes the effort to get up very early in the morning to prepare food since she sells breakfasts and lunches to very discerning customers, usually drivers who work for the nearby transportation companies. The meals that Nora makes are delicious and of high quality. After 20 years of supporting herself with this business, she would like to improve upon it and widen the selection of meals and beverages for her customers. This is her first loan with MFP, and she looks forward to joining all of the members of the communal bank in their solidary work. With the money that she is requesting, she will set herself up with the necessary items to sell fruit juices. First she will buy a blender, a juicer, and an extractor. With the rest of the money, she will buy the fruits she needs to meet this new challenge.

Translated from Spanish by Kelly Wester, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Outfit her business for selling fruit juices

loans.name: Gbassivi

texts.fr: Agée de quarante trois (43) ans, Mme Gbassivi E. est mariée avec trois (03) personnes à charge. Pour suppléer son mari dans les charges de la famille, elle mène des activités commerciales dont la principale est la vente de noix de palme dans les marchés de sa localité.  Toutefois, elle est confrontée à un manque crucial de fonds de roulement. C’est pourquoi elle sollicite un financement lui permettant de disposer suffisamment de fonds pour développer son commerce et augmenter ses revenus.
texts.en:
Ms. Gbassivi E., age 43, is married and has three people to support. To fill in for her husband in supporting the family, she works in commerce, where she mainly sells palm nuts at the marketplaces in her town. Nevertheless, she is confronted by a crucial lack of working capital. This is why she is requesting financing for having enough funds to develop her business and to increase her revenues.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell palm nuts

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence A. recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya.

As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin-enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

Florence is 42 years old, married, and the mother of 5 children, who are all in school. She and her family live in the Nyalenda area of Kisumu.

Florence has had a business in Kisumu selling fruit since the year 2000. She initially was only selling ripe bananas, but now she sells pineapples, oranges, and mangoes as well. Florence purchases stock from Kibuye Market in town. She decided to start this business because she knew that it would be profitable enough to pay for her family’s upkeep.

She has applied for her first loan from K-MET – a loan of approximately $200. Florence will use the loan to buy products cheaply in bulk.

loans.use: To purchase fruit in bulk

loans.name: Koffi

texts.fr: Mr Koffi A. est un jeune agriculteur de trente cinq (35) ans qui s’est finalement adonné aux cultures maraîchères faute de moyens financiers.  Son travail maraîcher marche très bien actuellement. Mr Koffi A. sollicite un financement pour augmenter sa surface cultivable, acheter des intrants afin de rendre son activité plus productive. Ceci lui permettra d’améliorer ses conditions de vie.
texts.en:
Mr. Koffi A. is a young farmer, 35 years of age, who has come to devoting all his time to market gardening due to a lack of financial means. This work of his is currently going very well. He is requesting financing to increase his arable land and to buy fertilizers and the like, so as to make his work more productive. This will enable him to improve his living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Gardens for growing produce for the markets

loans.name: Holadjam

texts.fr: Madame T.  vend des charbons de bois et céréales dans le quartier d’agoè qui est aussi son quartier de résidence, elle fait ce commerce depuis 1986  qui lui permette d’aider son mari dans les charges du foyer, elle a 05 enfants. Elle demande son premier crédit  de 500000f à wages pour acheter des charbons de bois et des céréales.
texts.en:
Ms. T. sells charcoal and grain in the Agoè district, which is also where she lives. She has been working in commerce since 1986, and it allows her to help her husband with household expenses. She has five children. She is asking WAGES for her first loan in the amount of 50,000 francs for buying charcoal and grain.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy charcoal

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Raising goats and sheep

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela A. recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya.

As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin-enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

Pamela is a 25-year-old widow and the mother of one child. She and her child live in the Nyalenda neighborhood of Kisumu.

In school, Pamela made it to form 2 of secondary school and then dropped out. After marrying, she was a housewife until her husband passed away. It was then, in 2005, that Pamela began a small business making and selling chapatti (a soft flat bread) and mandazi (a type of doughnut). She buys the ingredients from a wholesale business in town.

Pamela has applied for a loan of approximately $200. She will use the loan to boost her current business and buy more ingredients.

loans.use: To purchase baking ingredients

loans.name: Tonouwoèdé

texts.fr: Agée d’une quarantaine d’années, Mme A. Tonouwoèdé est une femme très dynamique qui a entrepris avec ses maigres moyens la vente de petits articles (bonbons, farine, sucre en poudre, savon omo) au bord de la rue .Afin de développer son activité pour un bon rendement,Mme A. souhaite construire un hangar pour s’abriter contre le soleil et la pluie Mais elle manque de moyens financiers .C’est pourquoi elle sollicite un financement pouvant lui permettre de mieux s’installer , s’approvisionner  régulièrement .Les bénéfices tirés de cette activité lui permettrons de mieux contribuer aux charges de famille.
texts.en:
Ms. Tonouwoèdé A. is forty-something and a very dynamic woman who, with her meager funds, has embarked upon selling small items (candy, flour, sugar, Omo soap) on the road side. In order to develop her business for a good return, she would like to construct a covered stall for shelter against the sun and rain. But she lacks the financial means. This is why she is requesting financing to enable her to do better in getting situated and in acquiring supplies regularly. The profits derived from this work will allow her to do more to help with family responsibilities.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell basic goods

loans.name: Ami Edzodzinam

texts.fr: Cette dame  habite le quartier d’adidogomé, elle est mariée et n’a pas d’enfants, elle  fait le commerce des articles de mercerie, elle fait ce commerce deuis 2006 et s’approvisionne au grand marché de lomé. Elle voudrait augmenter son stock de marchandise pour mieux satisfaire la demande par l’achat des articles de mercerie, c’est pour cela qu’elle demande à wages un prêt de 500000F.
texts.en:
This lady lives in the Adidogomé district; she is married and has no children. She sells sewing notions, a business she has been in since 2006. She buys her inventory in the big open-air market of Lomé. She would like to expand her inventory of merchandise and that is why she is requesting a loan of 500,000 F from WAGES.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of sewing notions for re-sale

loans.name: Maria Luisa

texts.en:
María Luisa, 43, is the mother of four children. She lives in Sumpango Sacatepequez, a town about one hour west of Guatemala City. She is a very entrepreneurial and resourceful woman who supports the betterment of her family by sending her children to school and improving the quality of their home.

María Luisa sells food products to the workers of a factory that is located in San Lucas Sacatepequez,  about 10 kilometers from her house. She began by selling a small number of food items but her customers asked for other items such as fruit, sodas, and candies. These requests gave María Luisa the idea of selling a greater variety of food items. By doing so, she knows that she can increase her revenue. She has also started making delicious meals to sell – and she now has a much bigger clientele. 

Her current capital isn’t enough to buy what she needs, so she is requesting a loan to help her grow the business. She feels very happy to be an important part of her family and to help support the education of her children. Her dream is to save and have a beautiful house someday and to see her children grow up to become professionals.


***************************************************



María Luisa, tiene 43 años, es madre de 4 hijos vive en el municipio de Sumpango Sacatepequez.  Ella es una mujer emprendedora y de mucha iniciativa, apoya en la superación de su familia en el estudio de sus hijos y en mejorar su vivienda, ella vende sus productos de alimentos, a los trabajadores de una fabrica que esta ubicada en San Lucas Sacatepequez aproximadamente a 10 kilómetros de su casa.  Ella empezó vendiendo pequeños alimentos,  luego sus clientes le pedían frutas, gaseosas, golosinas, quienes a la vez le dieron la idea de vender comida mas completa.  Ella se dio cuenta que así tendría mas ganancias, a partir de allí Ella prepara ricos platos de comida, y  tiene mas clientela.  Ahora su propio capital ya no es suficiente para su venta, por lo que necesita de un préstamo para poder crecer en su negocio.  Ella se siente muy contenta de poder ser parte importante de su familia, y apoya en la educación de sus hijos. Su sueño es ahorrar, y en el futuro tener una bonita casa y ver a sus hijos profesionales con sus estudios.

loans.use: Purchase variety of food products to sell

loans.name: Vita

texts.en:
Vita K. is married. She is a small entrepreneur from Zaporozhye. Vita sells women’s clothing in the central city market called “Yubileynyi”. She started this business 10 years ago. Presently, Vita has about 18,000 Grivnas in inventory. His current income is about 6,000 Grivnas each month. 

Vita’s business is self-sustainable. It has passed different formation stages; survival, growth and excellence in creating innovations and productivity. Today she is seeking a loan for 2,500 Grivnas to re-stock her merchandise for the spring season. Vita is hoping to generate additional income with new clothing products and increased sales. 

Note: this is a short term “seasonal” loan that will be paid back in two months.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of clothing items

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les dix femmes du groupe Benkadi sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 37ans et 5 enfants. Excepté deux qui n’ont pas de coépouses, elles vivent toutes dans les  familles traditionnelles polygames  à TDJILA chef lieu de commune dans la commune de WATENI situé dans la sous préfecture de NIENA de la 3ème région administrative du Mali.
 Elles menent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres l’achat – vente de céréales, de soumala, de canaris et  la restauration.
Elles collaborent  avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle ; elles sont à leur premier prêt (prêt solidaire) 
Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt, 10sacs de 100kg de céréales, 60 canaris, 150 kilogrammes de grains de Néré pour le soumbala et des condiments alimentaires pour la restauration. Elles s’approvisionnement  au marché de NIENA, de BOUGOULABA et de TDJILA. Les marchandises sont vendues marché de NIENA, de BOUGOULABA, de TDJILA et BAMAKO (soumbala); en détail et au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 7.625 FCFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The ten women of the Benkadi group are all married and are on average 37 years old with 5 children. Except for two who do not have co-wives, they all live in traditional polygamous families in Tdjila, the administrative centre in the commune of Wateni, situated in the sub-prefecture of Niena in the 3rd administrative region of Mali. They run various businesses, which include, among others, food preparation and the purchase and resale of cereals, soumbala (a type of condiment made from fermented néré seeds), and clay jars. They work together with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to meet the needs of their customers; they are seeking their first group loan. With this loan, they intend to buy ten 100-kg bags of cereals, 60 jars, 150 kilograms of néré seeds to make soumbala, and other condiments for food preparation. They supply themselves at the markets in Niena, Bougoulaba, and Tdjila. Their goods are sold at the markets in Niena, Bougoulaba, Tdjila, and Bamako (the soumbala), at retail in cash to a clientele composed of men and women. They each foresee generating an average monthly profit of 7,625 FCFA, of which one portion will be used for their families' needs and the rest invested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and re-sell cereals, soumbala (a West African condiment), clay jars, and other condiments

loans.name: Cesar Augusto

texts.es: Don Cesar tiene 39 años de edad, se desempeña como taxista en la ciudad de Managua, para el es difícil abecés ya que por falta de dinero la gente no aborda la carrera pero también hay día buenos, las dificultades que ha tenido es que les quitaron el subsidio, el Sr. Cesar reside en laureles norte, su esposa le tiene una niña que cursa la primaria. Con este crédito va invertir en infraestructura, en la construcción de un muro. Sus planes a futuro es comprar otra unidad de taxi y seguir dando un mejor servicio a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Mr. Cesar is 39 years old and works as a taxi driver in Managua. It is sometimes hard for him because people don’t have money to hire a taxi, but sometimes there are good days. He struggles because his subsidy has been taken away. Mr. Ceasar lives in Laureles Norte and he and his wife have a daughter who is in elementary school. With this loan he will invest in infrastructure and the construction of a wall. His future plans are to buy another taxi and continue to provide superior service to his clients.

Translated from Spanish by Mary McKee, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials to build a wall

loans.name: Messan

texts.fr: Mr A. Messan Jean –Marié est jeune homme de trente–deux (32) ans qui n’a pas eu la chance de poursuivre ses études faute de moyens financier. Très tôt, il s’est épris de passion pour le métier de photographe qu’il a appris auprès d’un oncle. Aujourd’hui, il évolue pour son propre compte dans ce métier mais il ne dispose pas de matériels nécessaires pour exercer convenablement son métier. C’est pourquoi il sollicite un financement pour acheter un appareil photo de qualité et une caméra pour ses reportages vidéo. Ce financement lui permettra de se professionnaliser comme un véritable photographe et d’augmenter ses revenus.
texts.en:
Mr. Messan Jean-Marié A. is a young man of 32 who did not have a chance to pursue his studies due to lack of financial means. Very early on, he became passionate about photography, a skill he learned from his uncle. Today he is working independently in this sphere, but he does not have the necessary materials to pursue his work correctly. This is the reason why he is requesting a loan to buy a good camera and a video-camera.This loan will permit him to become a true professional photographer and also to increase his earnings.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of a good camera and also a video-camera

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina Y. is a small entrepreneur from Vinogradovo. She is in the business of selling synthetic leather jackets and children’s clothing in a trading complex called “Veronika”. Irina has no competitors in this sphere of business. Moreover, financial assistance from Nadiya Ukraine added much to the success of Irina’s venture. Irina has been in this trade for 4 years. Currently, she has about 70,000 Grivnas in inventory. 

Irina’s business is characterized by stability and consistent growth. She has proven to be a reliable client as she has had a good credit history with Nadiya Ukraine ever since she got her first loan. One of the attractions of her business is Irina’s natural thoughtfulness and friendliness as she serves her customers. This makes buying from her a pleasant experience. Today she is requesting an 8,000 Grivna loan to re-stock her merchandise and purchase additional items for retail sale.

loans.use: To increase her inventory with a variety of clothing for resale

loans.name: Kokou

texts.fr: Mr Kokou A. est un maraîcher très doué dans la préfecture des Lacs au Sud du Togo. Marié et père de famille, la culture maraîchère est son activité principale à travers laquelle il tire l’essentiel de ses revenus. Ses clientes sont les revendeuses des grands marchés de Lomé. Mais il n’arrive plus à couvrir la totalité de leur demande compte tenu des moyens financiers insuffisant dont il dispose pour augmenter sa production. C’est pourquoi il sollicite un financement pour augmenter sa surface cultivable et acheter les intrants (engrais et semis). Ce crédit lui permettra de faire face aux demandes de ses clientes et d’augmenter ses revenus.
texts.en:
Mr. Kokou A. is a gifted market gardener in the Prefecture of the Lakes, in the south of Togo. Married and the father of a family, he earns his living mostly through market gardening. His customers are retailers from the big markets in Lomé. However, he is not able to fill all of their orders because insufficient financial means keep him from expanding his production. This is why he is requesting a loan to add to his arable land and purchase inputs (fertilizer and seeds). This loan will permit him to satisfy the needs of his customers and increase his income.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: market gardening (purchase of inputs)

loans.name: Benkelema Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre  femmes du groupe Benkelema de l’association Djidia  (toutes mariées) avec une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans et  4 enfants, vivent dans des  familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Bankorona l’un des villages de la sous préfecture de NIENA (distant de 2 km de NIENA) en 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles menent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres l’achat - vente d’haricots, de céréales, des articles de boutiques et des condiments alimentaires pour la restauration.
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de leurs clientèles, elles ont décidé de collaborer  avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt (prêt de groupe) et tous les précédents se sont bien dénoués.
Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt, 10 sacs de 100 kilogrammes de maïs, de mil, de riz, d’haricot, 20 litres d’huile d’arachide, 15 paquets de bonbon, 2 paquets d’allumettes et diverses sortes de condiments alimentaires pour la restauration. 
Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de NIENA et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 5.250FCFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans leurs activités.
Les femmes du groupe Benkelema ambitionnent  aménager un point de vente adéquat ou avoir un restaurant digne de ce nom ou d’être des grossistes.
texts.en:
The four women of the Benkelema group of the Djidia association, who are all married and are on average 32 years old with 4 children, live in traditional extended families in the village of Bankorona, one of the villages in the sub-prefecture of Niena (about 2 km from Niena itself) in the 3rd administrative region of Mali. They run various businesses which include, among others, the purchase and sale of beans, cereals, various articles, and condiments for food preparation. In order to meet the needs of their customers, they decided to work with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso 2 years ago. They are seeking their third group loan, and all their previous loans were repaid without problems. With this loan, they intend to buy ten 100-kilogram bags of maize, millets, rice, beans, 20 litres of peanut oil, 15 packs of sweets, 2 packs of matches, and various types of condiments for food preparation. They each foresee generating an average monthly profit of 5,250 FCFA, of which one portion will be used to meet their families' needs and the rest invested in their businesses. The women of the Benkelema group hope to establish a suitable retail outlet, or to have a reputable restaurant, or to become wholesalers.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cereals and condiments

loans.name: Bernard

texts.fr: Monsieur A. bernard vend des peintures, il habite le quartier de kohé à Agoè , il a pour activité  la vente de peinture, commerce qu’il fait dans sa boutique appelée « Ets AMEDESSE », il gfait ce commerce depuis 1998, la demande a augmenté , il sollicite un crédit de 500000F pour y faire face, il a djà obtenu un crédit de 300000 qu’il a remboursé, il est marié et a 03 enfants, sa femme est une coiffeuse.
texts.en:
Mr. Bernard A. sells paint. He lives in the Kohé district in Agoè. His shop is called “Ets AMEDESSE”, and he has been in this business since 1998. Demand has rise, so he is requesting a loan of 50,000 francs to address it. He has already obtained a loan of 300,000 francs, which he repaid. He is married and has three children. His wife is a hairdresser.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy paint

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice O. recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya.

As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin-enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

Alice is a 40-year-old married mother of 5. The family lives in the Nyalenda neighborhood of Kisumu.

Alice sells both raw and fried fish in the Nyalenda area. She began the business in 1980, and it has been faring well for over 28 years now. The fish, tilapia, comes fresh from Lake Victoria. She buys from fishermen at the lakeside as well as from middlemen near the Kisumu Bus Station.

She has applied for her first loan from K-MET, requesting approximately $150. Alice will use this loan to increase her stock of fish.

loans.use: To purchase fish

loans.name: Dodji

texts.fr: Agée de trente huit (38) ans, Mr Dodji D. est un conducteur de taxi moto qui ne travail pour son propre compte. Marié et père de famille, c’est à partir des revenus tirés de la conduite de taxi moto qu’il arrive à faire face aux dépenses de sa famille. Aujourd’hui il désire travailler pour lui-même en achetant sa propre moto et sollicite pour cela un financement. Ce crédit lui permettra d’être financièrement indépendant et de pouvoir s’occuper de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Dodji D., age 38, is a motorbike taxi driver who works for someone else. He is married and a father with a family. Earning an income from driving a moto taxi is how he is managing to deal with family expenses. Today, he would like to work for himself by buying his own moto and is requesting financing to do so. This loan will enable him to be financially independent and to take care of his family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a motorbike taxi

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To stock up on flour

loans.name: Ahlimba

texts.fr: Cette dame est une revendeuse d’oignons en gros et détails, l’oignon est un ingrédient très utilisé dans la cuisine togolaise, elle maitrise bien son commerce car elle le fait depuis 1990, elle s’approvisionne à l’abatoire au grand marché de lomé. Elle demande à wages son premier crédit de 500000 pour l’achat des sacs d’oignons. Elle est célibataire et avec le surplus qu’elle gagne elle arrive à aider sa famille.
texts.en:
Ahlimba is a lady who sells onions both in wholesale and in retail. Onions are widely used in the Togolese kitchen. She is well experienced and has been in the business since 1990. She buys her provisions at the central karketplace in Lome. Ahlimba is requesting her first loan from wages for 50,000 XOF ( $975.00) to buy sacks of onions. She is single and with the extra that she earns, she will help support her family.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies of onions

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina owns a rapidly growing business, selling groceries in the small town of Borky. She has been in this business for only 6 months but has already proven to be a very sharp business owner. Her husband, Yevgeniy, also helps with the business. Irina was able to purchase a storage container which helps her keep her inventory fresh. Another way she has been able to save money is to buy inventory directly from manufacturers rather than from middlemen suppliers. Presently, Irina has about 19,000 Grivnas in working capital.

Irina has requested a loan of 5,000 Grivnas to help her purchase additional merchandise. Irina loves what she is doing and is looking forward to the future. She and her husband are grateful for the opportunity this business has given, not only to provide for themselves, but also to help two of their children.

loans.use: Purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr: Agée de quarante six (46) ans, Mme Marie H. est mariée avec quatre (04) personnes à charge. Elle est propriétaire d’une boutique de vente de produits alimentaires et de produits de premières nécessités à Aného. Son dynamisme, son dévouement et la qualité de ses produits ont instauré une confiance énorme entre elle et ses clients qui ne cessent d’augmenter et d’être exigeants. Pour développer son commerce et faire face aux besoins de ses clients, elle sollicite un financement. Ce crédit lui permettra de rentabiliser son activité et d’accroître ses bénéfices.
texts.en:
Ms. Marie H., age 46, is married and has four people to support. She is the owner of a shop selling food items and basic goods in Aného. Her dynamism, devotion, and the quality of her products have established enormous trust between her and her customers, who are continually increasing and demanding. To develop her commerce and to address their needs, she is requesting financing. This loan will enable her to make her work profitable and to grow her profits.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To supply her shop with merchandise

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth A. O. recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya.

As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin-enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

Elizabeth joined K-MET because she was interested in the health and nutrition training that K-MET provides; she was also interested in taking out a loan.

Elizabeth is an early childhood development teacher. She has been teaching for 9 years and this year, on January 5, 2009, she opened her own school for young children.

Fifty children are currently enrolled at Elizabeth’s school and registration continues. The school is located in the Nyalenda area of Kisumu.

Elizabeth has applied for her first loan from K-MET in order to purchase furniture and school materials like reading charts, flash cards, chalk, and books. She is requesting approximately $275.

Elizabeth is 34 years old, married, and has 3 children, 2 of whom are in primary school, while the third attends Elizabeth’s school.

loans.use: To purchase furniture and school materials

loans.name: Caflim Yessenia

texts.en:
Caflim Yessenia S. has been selling women's clothing for 20 years. She spends extra time making sure that she offers excellent service to her clients and that her products are of good quality.

In addition to selling women’s clothes, she also sells bedding and other products by mail order, which has enabled her to increase her profits. 

Caflin has five children, all of whom are in school. Her husband helps sell the bedding products in the many towns and communities around Guatemala City. 

She is requesting a loan so she can buy more merchandise, including some new products that will enable her to expand her business and increase her sales.

***********************************

Caflim Jessenia tiene 20 años de tener su negocio de venta de ropa para mujer, ella dedica su tiempo en ofrecerles a sus clientes un buen servicio y sus productos son de buena calidad.

Además de vender ropa para mujer, ella también vende ropa de cama, y otros productos por catalogo para mujer, y de esta forma puede obtener mas ganancias.

Caflin tiene 5 hijos, y todos están estudiando.  Su esposo le ayuda en la venta de ropa de cama, la cual vende en forma ambulante en varios lugares del interior del país.

Con el préstamo que ella esta solicitando, ella quiere comprar más mercadería, contar con nuevos productos, y poder así ampliar su negocio e incrementar sus ventas.

loans.use: Increase merchandise and expand product selection

loans.name: Kodjo

texts.fr:
Mr Kodjo K. est un jeune éleveur âgé de trente deux (32) ans. Marié et père de famille, il est un grand éleveur de porcs  dans son village. C’est cette activité qui lui procure suffisamment de moyens financiers lui permettant de subvenir aux besoins de sa famille. Actuellement il ne dispose pas d’un enclos convenable pour bien protéger ses animaux afin d’éviter leur errance et leur vol. C’est pourquoi il sollicite un financement pour construire un enclos, augmenter ses têtes de bétail et acheter des produits vétérinaires pour les animaux.
Ce financement va lui permettre de mieux rentabiliser son activité et augmenter ses revenus.
texts.en:
Mr. Kodjo K. is a young livestock farmer, 32 years of age, married, and a father with a family. He raises pigs on a large scale in his village. This business is what brings in sufficient earnings for him to provide for his family. He currently lacks a suitable corral for really protecting his animals, so as to prevent them from straying or being stolen. This is why he is requesting financing for constructing fencing, having more animals, and buying veterinary products for his animals. This financing will allow him to make his work profitable and to increase his revenues.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To raise pigs

loans.name: Marat

texts.en:
Marat is married with a 10-year-old daughter. His family lives in Kherson. Marat is a private entrepreneur selling sports footwear in the central city market. Marat is very disciplined. One of his strong characteristics is his ability to listen and persuade, which helps him in his work with customers. Marat has been in the market for 10 years. Today he has about 60,000 Grivnas invested in his business. 

Marat‘s main goal is to provide his family with a decent life and stable future. He has always tried to achieve financial and economic independence and make a career. Marat is hoping to see his business flourish and succeed. He believes this loan of 9,000 Grivnas will be one of the steps towards this goal. Marat has repaid 15 loans to Nadiya Ukraine without any delinquencies.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of inventory

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian A. A. recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya.

As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin-enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

Vivian is 35, married, and the mother of 5 children. Two of her children are in secondary school, while the other 3 attend primary school.

Vivian is a shopkeeper in the Nyalenda neighborhood of Kisumu. She has been running her shop since 1996, selling bread, milk, kimbo (vegetable fat), etc. She opened her own business in order to make money so that she could pay her children’s school fees, and she chose this type of shop because it is easy for her.

Vivian is applying for her first loan from K-MET, in the amount of approximately $400. She will use this money to purchase more items for the store.

loans.use: To purchase food items

loans.name: Amistad 4 Group

texts.en:
The Amistad Bank of Hope is now starting its 8th loan cycle with Esperanza International. Ana F. is the group coordinator for these five ladies. Ana is a single mother of 3 children. Her business consists of making hair products; shampoo, conditioner and anti-frizz serum, as well as disinfectant for floors and home surfaces. Ana purchases chemical products from local distributors to make her products and packs them for distribution. Her finished products are sold in small grocery stores and in her own home.

She hopes to see her children become professionals, which is one reason why she invests so much time and energy into her small business: to produce profits to allow her to proviD. a good education for her children. She also set a goal of buying a pickup truck a year from now to sell her products in other communities and outsiD. her province to expand her clientele. 

She thinks Esperanza International´s support through loans will help her achieve her dreams. On behalf of these entrepreneurs and Esperanza International, thank you for supporting this loan!

loans.use: purchase chemicals to make hair products and cleaning products

loans.name: Abou

texts.fr: Ce monsieur a pour activité génératrice de revenus la vente de produits congelés et d’alimentation, il vend ses produits à des restaurants et aussi à des particuliers. Il fait ce commerce depuis 2001, la demande de ses clients est de plus en plus grandissant c’est pour cela qu’il sollicite un crédit de 500000f pour acheter des produits congelés et d’alimentation, il est mariée à une dame qui est revendeuse et ils ont 03 enfants à charge
texts.en:
This gentleman’s income-generating work involves selling frozen foods and supplies. He sells these goods to restaurants and also to individuals. He has been in this commerce since 2001. The demand from his customers is growing more and more. That’s why he’s requesting a loan of 500,000 francs to buy frozen goods. He is married to a lady who is a retailer, and they have three children to support.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy frozen foods and other goods

loans.name: Yvette

texts.fr: Agée de trente-cinq (35) ans, Mme Yvette K. est mariée avec trois (03) personnes à charge. Elle est propriétaire d’une boutique de vente de produits alimentaires et de produits de premières nécessités. Son dynamisme, son dévouement et la qualité de ses produits ont instauré une confiance énorme entre elle et ses clients qui ne cessent d’augmenter. Pour développer son commerce et faire face aux besoins de ses clients, elle sollicite un financement. Ce crédit lui permettra d’améliorer ses conditions de vie, rentabiliser son activité et accroître ses bénéfices.
texts.en:
Ms. Yvette K., age 35, is married and has three people to support. She is the owner of a shop selling food items and essential goods. Her dynamism, devotion, and the quality of her products have instilled enormous trust between her and her customers, who are ever-growing in number. To develop her commerce and to address the needs of her customers, she is requesting financing. This loan will enable her to improve her living conditions, to make her business profitable, and to grow her revenues.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell food items

loans.name: Yekaterina

texts.en:
Yekaterina S. owns a vending facility in the central city market selling women’s clothing. She has been in this trade for 3 years. Her turnover capital has doubled since she started her small business.She is divorced with a 6-year-old son Sergei. She lives in Kherson, Ukraine

Yekaterina has a perfect credit history in Nadiya, Ukraine. She has repaid all her loans without any delinquencies. Yekaterina believes a loan of 5,000 (UAH) will help her increase her working capital and profits. She wants to purchase more variety of women's clothing and expand her marketing area. Yekaterina has become a entrepreneur through hard work and dedication and believe this will help her succeed in the future.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of clothing items

loans.name: Adjowavi

texts.fr: Mme Adjowavi M.  est  une femme de quarante-cinq (45) ans  avec quatre (04)  personnes à charge .Elle s’est  adonnée à l’agriculture  pour mettre en pratique son savoir faire. Ce qui  marche très bien actuellement. Mme Adjowavi M.   sollicite un financement pour augmenter sa surface cultivable, acheter des intrants afin de rendre son activité plus productive. Ceci lui permettra d’améliorer ses conditions de vie et bien veiller à l’éducation de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Mrs. Adjowavi M. is a 45 year old woman who is caring for 4 people. She is devoted to farming, where she can put into practice all her experience. This business is going well. Mrs. Adjowavi M. is requesting a loan to strengthen her soil surface by buying fertilizers to increase its productivity. This would allow her to improve her living conditions and insure her children's education.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to increase the soils productivity

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline A. O. recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya.

As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin-enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

Caroline is 31 years old, married, and has 4 children; 3 are in school, and the fourth is still too young to attend. She lives with her family in the small village of Dunga on the outskirts of Kisumu.

Caroline used to manage a children’s orphanage in Kisumu and was offered a post to manage another orphanage in Nairobi; however, when they discovered she was pregnant she was dismissed. She now has a shop in Dunga, where she sells foodstuffs and small household goods.

Caroline’s husband used to have a small business selling secondhand shoes at the bus station in Kisumu, but during the post-election violence his business was destroyed. Caroline now provides the family’s income while her husband continues to look for more permanent work beyond the small jobs he does currently.

Along with running a shop, Caroline teaches reading and writing to adults. She has been teaching for 3 years. There are 50 adults enrolled in her class, but daily attendance varies between 5 to 10 people, as schedules do not allow students to attend daily.

Caroline was interested in joining K-MET in order to learn about health education that she may pass on to her adult students. She would like to be able to teach them about family planning and nutrition, as well as the reading and writing.

Caroline has applied for her first loan from K-MET, in the amount of approximately $275. She will use the loan to purchase more stock for her shop: foodstuffs and household goods like bleach.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs and household goods

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.fr: Cette dame habite le quartier de gblinkomé à lomé, elle mariée et a un enfant, elle a pour activité génératrice de revenu la vente des accessoires informatiques et bureautiques et gestion de cyber, elle fait cette activité depuis 2005.elle voudrait diversifier son commerce, c’est pour cela qu’elle sollicite de wages un crédit de 500000f pour l’’achat des accessoires informatiques et autres.
texts.en:
This is a woman who lives in the Gblinkomé district in Lomé and who is married and has a child. She earns an income from selling accessories for the office, computers, and internet café management. She has been in this business since 2005. She would like to diversify her business, which is why she’s requesting from WAGES a loan of 500,000 francs CFA for buying computer accessories and more.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy computer accessories

loans.name: Jose

texts.es: JOSE, CON 38 AÑOS DE EDAD, REALIZA CONSTRUCCIONES DE OBRAS CIVILES, ES INDEPENDIENTE Y TRABAJA CON PERSONAS PARTICULARES.
