This loan will be used to buy diverse types of products, to expand their businesses selling food and also to buy materials and ingredients. The members will then be able to increase their income and provide their families with a better quality of life. The members of this group have received two previous loans and they have been able to prove that they are punctual with making their payments. They are thankful for the opportunities that the foundation has given them by providing them with financing for their businesses.

(Translated by Nikki of San Roque High School)

Translated from Spanish by Kendra Gaete, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital for Businesses

loans.name: Gertrudis Ramona

texts.es: La señora Gertrudis Ramona Hernández M. tiene 52 años, está soltera, y tiene dos hijos de 26 y 23 años, respectivamente. Hace veintidós años que Doña Gertrudis trabaja como un vendedor de pan en una repostería, y sus propósitos por este negocio son de seguir con salud y seguir trabajando para brindarle apoyando a sus hijos. Doña Gertrudis inició a este negocio por la necesidad de facilitarles a sus hijos el pan de cada día debido a que el padre los abandonó. Por esta razón, ella decidió hacerse cargo de su familia para generar una fuente de ingresos. El financiamiento de Kiva es para capital de trabajo ya que necesita realizar la compra de leña, azúcar, huevo y levadura.
texts.en:
Ms. Gertrudis Ramona H. M. is 52 years old. She is single and has two sons who are 26 and 23 years old, respectively. For 22 years Ms. Gertrudis has been selling bread in a confectioner's shop, and her goals are to keep healthy and to continue working to keep on supporting her sons. Ms. Gertrudis started this business out of the need to give her children their daily bread since their father abandoned them. For this reason, she decided to take charge of her family by creating a source of income. The Kiva loan is for working capital since she needs to purchase wood, sugar, eggs and yeast.

Translated from Spanish by Esteban Riojas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Santa Teresa Group

texts.es: Las socias del banco comunal "Santa Teresa", son socias que  se conocen entre si;  existe un parentesco consanguíneo entre la familia G. A. y de afinidad ninguno. El grupo se encuentra representado por la señora María Ruth y conformada por 15 miembros que se dedican al rubro comercial desempeñando diferentes actividades comerciales, conocen su negocio y con la experiencia de otros créditos saben la importancia de ser cumplidas para tener un financiamiento continuo. Las socias integrantes desempeñan diferentes actividades como: promotoras  cosméticos, venta de ropa y tienda de abarrotes y los socios participantes uno se encuentra en rubro de transporte y el otro socio es electrónico. En cuanto a la competencia se puede decir que ellas están conscientes de la misma pero confían en la capacidad de administrar bien el crédito y favorece para mejorar su negocio y la calidad de sus productos.  El crédito que se les otorgó esta destinado para aumentar su mercadería, comprar material de trabajo y compra de herramientas para desempeñar mejor sus labores diarias. En lo que respecta a experiencia se puede decir que una mayoría de las socias ya trabajaron con la fundación agrocapital por lo que conocen de la responsabilidad y el cumplimiento con sus obligaciones para ser cliente de la institución.
texts.en:
The members of the communal bank "Santa Teresa" are members that all know each other. Two of the members are related and are from the G. family. This group is represented by Mrs. Maria Ruth and is composed of 15 people who are all entrepreneurs that have different types of businesses. Their businesses include selling cosmetics, running small grocery stores, selling clothing, and one of the male members works in transportation and another works as an electrician. In terms of competition, they all are aware of it but they all are confident in their abilities to make a living and to be responsible about repaying their loan. They all want to use the loans to improve their businesses and the quality of their products. The loan that they are asking for will be used to purchase merchandise, buy materials and tools so that they can increase their income. In terms of the experience of all of the group members, it can be said that the majority of the members have worked with the "agrocapital" foundation and they know about the responsibility that they have to meet the obligations they have by being a member of that institution.

(Translated by Mariela of San Roque High School)

Translated from Spanish by Kendra Gaete, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital for Businesses

loans.name: Silvia Estela

texts.es: la Sra. Silvia M. U. nos comento que tiene 20 años de dedicarse a este tipo de actividad generadora de ingresos, lo que le ha permitido salir adelante, pues a traves de esta actividad logro graduarse de licenciada en Pedagogia y ha podido conseguir trabajo en un instituto de secundaria y a su vez apoyar al padre de sus hijos en la formacion profesional de sus 4 hijos, uno de los sueños de silvia es poner su propia academia donde pueda instruir a sus alumnos en confecciones de tela.
texts.en:
Silvia M. U. has told us that she has worked for 20 years at this income generating activity, which has allowed her to get by. During this time she has also graduated with a teaching degree and has found work in a secondary school. This has allowed her to support the father of her children in providing vocational training for their 4 children. One of her dreams is to have her own school where she can teach students how to make clothing.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Martyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing materials to make clothing

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Juana De Los Angeles

texts.es: Juana de los Ángeles M. D. tiene 52 años, está soltera, y tiene seis hijos que trabajan de forma independiente. Por los últimos veinte años, Juana ha vendido productos médicos, y esta actividad ha producido grandes ganancias. A un momento, ella necesitaba un ingreso extra para su familia y fue así que decidió emprender este negocio. Juana hace todos los negocios desde su casa, y por eso, a ella le gustaría el financiamiento de Kiva para aprovechar la demanda de los clientes en su propio barrio. Al final, sus aspiraciones son de mantener su negocio y diariamente poder surtir su inventario.
texts.en:
Juana de los Ángeles M. D. is 52 years old, single, and has 6 grown children who live on their own and support themselves. For the past 20 years Juana has sold medical products, and with this business she has produced large profits. At one time she needed extra income for her family, so she decided to start this business. Juana runs her business from her home, and she would like Kiva’s financing to take advantage of the customer’s needs in her own neighborhood. Her aspirations include continuing her business and daily being able to stock her inventory.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Rosas Rojas Group

texts.es:
este grupo se llama Rosas Rojas y esta integrado de la siguiente forma:
Guadalupe del Carmen D.: la actividad principal de ella es el comercio, tiene 11 años y medio de dedicarse a la venta de oro, actividad que realiza de manera ambulante y es notable que durante ese tiempo lo ha sabido administrar, ya que con los ingresos que le ha generado este negocio a apoyado a su esposo a brindarles educacion a sus hijas, las cuales ahora son profesionales, ella es casada y del matrimonio ya solo depende un hijo de la familia, su esposo se dedica a la agricultura. 
Marta G. N.: ella tiene 12 años de haber iniciado con su negocio de pulperia, la cual opera bajo el nombre de pulperia Suyapita, en la actualidad ella es madre y padre para sus hijos ya que su compañero de hogar migro a USA en busca de mejores condiciones de vida, tiene 3 hijos los cuales estan cursando la secundaria. ella los mantiene y su esposo le manda remesas con las cuales les hace mejoras a la casa.
Gladys R.: ella tiene 6 años de haber iniciado con una pulperia, la cual opera bajo el nombre de Pulperia R., este tipo de negocio es muy comun en nuestro ambito social, las pulperias se encuentran ubicadas muy cerca la una con la otra y se ganan los clientes a quienes les brindan mejor la atencion. ella es casada pero no tiene hijos, su esposo trabaja como policia penitenciario en Tamara Departamento de Francisco Morazan, sus condiciones de vida han mejorado notablemente, ya que no dependen solo del sueldo de su esposo, sino tambien de los ingresos de la pulperia.
Nora Argentina R.: se dedica a la venta de verduras, actividad a la cual se dedica hace 4 años, dicho negocio lo lleva a cabo con su compañero de hogar, ella es madre de 2 hijos los cuales dependen al 100% de ellos, las verduras las compra en el mercado mayoreo de tegucigalpa y algunas veces en la ciudad de Danli, ella compra el producto los dias jueves de todas las semanas y los distribuye de manera ambulante en diferentes comunidades, aldeas y caserios de la zona de jamastran, esto lo hace en un carro que es propiedad de su esposo, su esposo de lunes a jueves se dedica a transportar lacteos en su carro. esto le genera ingresos aparte de la venta de verduras.
texts.en:
This group is named Red Roses and is organized as follows: Guadalupe del Carmen D.: Her principal activity is trade. She has spent 11 and a half years selling gold, which she does by foot. In this time she has learned administration, and with the money she has earned she has been able to support her husband in educating their two daughters, who are now professionals themselves. She is married and has only one child still as a dependant. Her husband works as a farmer. Marta G. N.: Began her convenience store 12 years ago, which operates under the name of Pulperia Suyapita. She acts as mother and father for her children, as her partner emigrated to the United States in search of better living conditions. She has three children who are in secondary school. She takes care of them and her husband sends money back, which they use to make improvements on their home. Gladys R.: Began her convenience store, Pulperia R., 6 years ago. This type of business is very common in the area, convenience stores are located very close to eachother, and htose which provide the best service earn the most customers. She is married but has no children, and her husband works as a prison guard. Their living conditions have improved notably now that they no longer depend only on the husband's salary, but as well on the income from the convenience store. Nora Argentina R.: Works selling vegetables, which she has done for 4 years. This business was created with her husband, with whom she has two children who depend on them 100%. The vegetables are bought in the major market in Tegucigalpa and sometimes in the city of Danli as well. She makes her purchases every Thursday, and distributes them on foot to different communities, villages, and farmhouses in the region of Jamastran. This is done in a cart belonging to her husband, which he uses to distribute dairy products from Monday to Thursday, in order to generate more money than the vegetables alone would earn.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Martyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing gold, sugar, butter, soaps, sanitary napkins, corn flour, rice, chicken, coffee, beans, and dairy products.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Horlinda

texts.es: Horlinda tiene 55 años, vive con su esposo en la casa que heredaron de sus padres hace muchos años atrás. El trabajo y su optimismo son rasgos que son muy evidentes en ella y que la ayudaron a tener no tan solo el negocio de abarrotes, sino algunas chacras de cultivo de uvas en la ciudad de Cañete (cuidad que se encuentra en el norte de la capital) donde viene trabajando junto a su esposo pues ella administra el negocio que instaló ahí (en la foto Herlinda nos muestra las imágenes de su bodega en Cañete) y que está iniciando ahora en la ciudad de Lima, lugares donde tiene que movilizarse cada quincena, pues las ventas son muy buenas por la temporada de verano. Es así que Horlinda viene trabajando más de 20 años en esta actividad  que le sirvió como alternativa para educar a sus hijos quienes ahora son profesionales y agradecen el esfuerzo de su madre y tratan de cooperar con ella. Sin embargo, desea incrementar el capital de su tienda y convertirla en un negocio familiar que sea herencia para sus hijos y nietos. Este es su décimo préstamo con MFP, pues es una de las señoras que acompaña a la  institución desde su creación como agencia en esta parte de la ciudad. Horlinda necesita 2500 soles para instalar teléfonos públicos en su bodega y así tener mayor demanda y clientela.
texts.en:
Horlinda is 55 years old and lives with her husband in the house that they inherited from her parents. Hard work and optimism, traits that she clearly displays, have helped her set up not only a general store, but also some grape farms in the city of Cañete—a city that is located to the north of the capital. She has been working alongside her husband because she manages the business that she set up there. Herlinda is showing pictures of her general store in Cañete. She is now setting up a business in Lima, where she must travel every two weeks, since sales are good during this summer season. For over 20 years, Horlinda has been in business, which has served as a way to provide an education for her children who are now professionals and are grateful for their mother’s efforts, so they try to cooperate with her. Nevertheless, she needs to increase her capital so that she can turn her general store into a family business that her children and grandchildren will inherit. This is her tenth loan with MFP since she is one of the women who have been working with the institute since it was founded in this part of the city. Horlinda needs 2500.00 PEN in order to install some public telephones in her general store so that she can increase her clientele.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Install public telephones in her general store

loans.name: Maria Auxiliadora

texts.es: María Auxiliadora S. Calderón tiene 47 años, está soltera, y tiene tres hijos. La actividad económica de Doña María es la venta de mercadería en general, y la ubicación de su negocio está en el  mercado municipal. Doña María empezó con este negocio hace tres anos, y poco a poco, ella le convirtió un negocio de perfumes, cremas, y otros productos del hogar a un negocio de ropa y calzado. En este sentido, sus propósitos son de ampliar su negocio para comprar otros lugares en donde pueda vender sus productos. Doña María lleva solicitando tres créditos con Fundación León 2000 y estos han sido de ayuda para la inversión de su negocio. Con el financiamiento de Kiva, destinado Doña María invertir en un amplio inventario de ropa, calzado y pequeños electrodomésticos. El monto que solicita es de C$ 14.500 a un plazo de 12 meses.
texts.en:
María Auxiliadora S. Calderón is 47 years, single, and has three children. María sells general merchandise, and her business is located in the municipal market. María began this business three years ago, and little by little, she converted her business from one selling perfumes, creams, and other home products into a business selling clothing and shoes. She proposes expanding her business to buy other places where she can sell her products. María has had three loans from Fundación León 2000 and these have been a help investing in her business. With Kiva’s financing, María will invest in an ample inventory of clothing, shoes and small electrical appliances. She is seeking C$ 14.500 which will be repaid over 12 months.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: El Surcador Group

texts.es:
Este banco está denominado "EL SURCADOR", Cuenta con 14 miembros activos, de los cuales tenemos a 11 mujeres y 03 varones; Estos socios pertenecen a la comunidad alto andina de Pancarhuaylla, de la provincia de Anta.

En está zona rural los socios se dedican principalmente a la agricultura, ellos cultivan papa, habas, trigo, cebada, maíz, también alternan está actividad con la ganadería, compran animales vacunos y porcinos, que en su respectivo momento ellos venderán estos animales a mayor precio.

Nuestras socias mujeres directamente se dedican a cultivar sus tierras y alternan sus actividades con otros pequeños negocios que ellas mismas se crearon en la zona, son socios que tienen muchas ganas de realizar sus sueños y dar mejor educación a sus menores hijos;  Todos los socios de este banco, hacen llegar a Ustedes su saludo afectuoso y agradecen vuestra ayuda mediante el préstamo otorgado y comprometiéndose así a pagar en el plazo estipulado.
texts.en:
This group called "El Surcador" has 14 active members - 11 women and 3 men. These members belong to the community Alta Andina of Pancarhuaylla in the province of Anta. In this rural area, the members mainly dedicate themselves to farming. They grow potatoes, beans, wheat, barley and corn and also raise livestock. They buy cattle and pigs which they sell at their respective times at the highest price. The women members of the group directly farm their lands and alternate this work with other small businesses that they established in this area. These members want badly to fulfill their dreams so that they can give their children a better education. All the members want to give you an affectionate greeting, thank you for your help with this loan and promise to pay within the stipulated time.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Manzo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase and sale of livestock, purchase fertilizer and seeds.

loans.name: Juana De La Concepcion

texts.es: Juana de la Concepción M. tiene 58 años, está soltera, y tiene un hijo de 12 años. Hace quince años que Doña Juana ha tenido un negocio de una pulpería y venta de ropa, lo cual esta en su casa de habitación. Doña Juana dio inicio a este negocio con fondos propios ya que necesitaba buscar una alternativa de obtener ingresos para su hogar, y por eso, decidió incursionar en este negocio pensando en el bienestar de su familia. El financiamiento de Kiva es para capital de trabajo por lo que Doña Juana necesita incrementar su negocio para la compra de granos básicos, cosméticos, ropa y golosinas. Al final, sus deseos son de incrementar su negocio, tener mejores ingresos, y a la misma vez, mejorar la calidad de vida para su hijo. La cantidad que solicita es de C$ 10.500 córdobas a un plazo de 9 meses.
texts.en:
Juana de la Concepción M. is 58 years old, single, and has a 12 year old son. 15 years ago Juana started a general store and sold clothing from her home. Juana began this business with her own funds as she needed to look for an alternative means of obtaining income for her home, and so she decided to open this business, thinking about her family’s well-being. Kiva’s financing will be working capital because Juana needs to increase her business by buying basic grains, cosmetics, clothing, and candy. Her dreams are to grow her business, have greater income, and at the same time, improve the quality of life for her son. She is seeking C$ 10.500 córdobas which will be repaid over 9 months.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Claudia Azucena

texts.es: La señora Claudia Azucena C. P. tiene 37 años, está casada, y tiene dos hijos de 12 y 15 años. La actividad económica de Doña Claudia es comercio de cosméticos, y hace diez años que ella ha vendido estos productos. Doña Claudia dio inicio a este negocio por una amiga, ya que se afilio a una casa comercial y por pequeñas cantidades es que ha podido colocar los productos y ofrecerlos a sus clientes. El motivo del financiamiento de Kiva es para capital de trabajo destinado para la compra de más productos de ropa y calzado. Al final, los sueños de Doña Claudia son de tener su propia tienda o distribuidora de productos de belleza, por lo que este ha sido uno de los negocios que más le ha gustado y que ha contribuido al desarrollo de su familia.
texts.en:
Mrs. Claudia Azucena C. P. is 37 years old, married, and has two children ages 12 and 15. Claudia sells cosmetics and she has been selling these products for 10 years. Claudia began this business through a friend, she affiliated with a commercial house and with small quantities she has been able to acquire products and sell them to her clients. She is seeking Kiva’s financing for working capital to buy more clothing and shoes. Claudia dreams of having her own store or becoming a distributor of beauty products, as this has been one of the businesses she has enjoyed the most and that has contributed to her family’s development.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rous

texts.en: Rous T., 46, of Siem Reap, Cambodia, stays at home doing housework and cooking for the family members while her husband is employed as a construction worker at Angkor Wat Temple, earning $130 every month, a little more than $4 a day. They have four children, one employed in construction, another as a security guard, and two who are students.  Rous would like to take out a loan of $500 to repair her leaky roof, which is very troublesome during the rainy season.

loans.use: To repair her leaky roof.

loans.name: Ouch

texts.en: Mrs.Ouch P., 58, is a widow who has three children, all of whom are married and live separately. Mrs. P. cultivates rice and vegetables crops on her own farmland, and has been rice farming since 1989.  Mrs.P. faces a problem, she has no cow to help her plow the farmland. Therefore, she is requesting a loan to buy a cow. The loan will allow her to better plow her farmland and provide her with an additional asset. Ouch P. lives in Pursat Province, Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Suy

texts.en:
Mrs Suy C. , age 24, has been raising pigs from her home for eight years. She currently takes care of three children; all of them are still young.  She married to Sinoun, 29, who is a local rice farmer.They live together in Pursat Province. 

In the past, C.’s husband always hired a buffalo from a neighbor to plow his farmland and he now hopes to own a buffalo. Therefore, C. is asking for a loan to purchase a water buffalo to be used for her husband’s farming business.

loans.use: To purchase a water buffalo for plowing

loans.name: Soeung

texts.en:
Mrs. Soeung C. was born in 1963 and is the good mother of four children.Three of her children are single and the other one is married. One single child is employed as a garment worker in Phnom Penh City. Mrs. C. is a rice farmer and her husband is a domestic building worker. They live in Pursat Province, Cambodia. 

To reduce the cost of transportation for the family’s daily transports, the couple is applying for a $600 loan to purchase a motorcycle and will be used by them to ride to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Much

texts.en: Much N., 37, a widow who lives with her five children in Siem Reap, Cambodia, works as an authority at Angkor Temple and makes $40 per month. Two of her children are in school and one is employed as an authority at Angkor Temple. Mrs. N. is requesting a loan of $600 to repair her house and start a new business selling souvenirs.

loans.use: To repair her house and sell souvenirs.

loans.name: Suon

texts.en: C., age 27, lives in a small village in Pursat Province where she raises pigs, next to her house. She normally sells all her pigs to a buyer five or six months after she begins raising them. She lives with her husband and three children. Her husband’s name is Sina, age 25. He earns a living cultivating rice crop. As the dry season is coming, C.’s husband plans to plant rice but he is not enough operating capital. Therefore, C. is requesting a loan for her husband to use for growing rice and to buy a water buffalo for plowing the field.

loans.use: To buy a water buffalo for plowing a field

loans.name: Chhuon

texts.en:
Chhuon S., 32, resides with her husband in Siem Reap, Cambodia, where she maintains the house and cooks for her family. Her husband has a dirt-selling business whereby he transports dirt to sell at construction sites. He also operates a battery-charging business from his home, on average earning a total daily profit of $3.  This couple has two young children. Chhuon is now requesting a loan of $700 to purchase a better generator for the battery-charging service. 

Mrs. Chhuon is pictured with her husband and two children.

loans.use: To purchase a generator.

loans.name: Kaing

texts.en: V., aged 42,  has been growing rice for more than 18 years, and she can grow both seasons, rainy season and dry season. She learned her farming skills from her grandparents. She is married to Born, 44, who works with her in the business. She's a good mother of five children: four are teenagers who are attending school and the other is married and lives away from the family home. V. is asking for a loan as capital to buy buffalo to raise for sale and use them to do rice in the dry season. (V.'s husband is pictured because she was not available.)

loans.use: To buy buffalo to raise for sale

loans.name: San

texts.en:
P. is 45 years old and has been running a small store next to her house for more then eight years, selling grilled meatballs to neighbors in the village. She normally earns approximately US$ 3 per day to help cover the family’s living expenses.

P. is married to Beunsong, 49, who is a domestic car repairman. She has eleven children: nine are single and the other are married. Three of her single children are employed; one of them (a son) is working as a local blacksmith. P. is applying for a US$ 1000 loan for her son to use as capital to buy ferrous equipment to fulfill his customers' needs. The family lives in Banteay Meanchey Province, Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy ferrous equipment

loans.name: Rous

texts.en:
Rous N., 41, is married and lives with her husband in Siem Reap, Cambodia. Since 2000, she has worked growing and selling rice at the market to earn an approximate US$ 4 every day. Her husband, pictured here, makes about US$ 3 by working as construction worker building houses. This couple has six children, four who are in school and two who are construction workers.

Mrs. Rous N. would like to take out a loan to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work. This will reduce the money that her husband spends every day on public transportation.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for family transport

loans.name: Nuk

texts.en: N. is a 48-year-old widower and he earns his living by driving a taxi motorbike, earning an average of US$ 4.50 each day. He currently begins his business early in the morning, picking up passengers and coming back home in the evening with his income. Beside this, he also is a rice farmer. He is a very responsible father for his one child who is a teenager. N. is requesting a loan of $500 to plant rice in the dry season. The loan will allow them to have more income.

loans.use: To plant rice in the dry season

loans.name: Prom

texts.en:
S., 56, lives in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. She earns a living by selling groceries from her house, selling items such as cooked food and sweets for kids. She has experience in this business for nine years. S. is a widow and has three children: one attends school, and the other two are married and live separately.

S. works very hard every day and is a very responsible mother to her family. Recently, she sold a lot of the groceries from her store, and because grocery selling is S.'s main way to earn an income to support her family, she asked for a loan. She would use any remaining amount to build additional grocery display space.

loans.use: To purchase a range of groceries for sale

loans.name: Dom

texts.en:
D., 30, who lives in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, earns a living selling souvenir items for tourists. working near Angkor Wat Temple. She has experience in this business for four years. D. is married and currently takes care of two children, both of whom attend school. Her husband works selling souvenirs as well.

D. works very hard every day and is very responsible with regard to her family. Recently, she had sold a lot of the items from her store, and because souvenir-selling is D.'s main way to earn an income to support her family, she asked for a loan of US$ 1,000 to purchase a range of souvenir items for sale. Any remaining money would be used to build additional display space.

loans.use: To purchase a range of souvenir items for sale

loans.name: Sann

texts.en:
Sann V. is 45 years old and sells food in Siem Reap province. Her business has been around for about four years and she makes US$ 1.50 every day, while her husband makes US$ 5 a day, selling wood. She and her husband have three children, one of whom is in school and two who are employed.

Mrs. Sann V. is asking for a loan of US$ 1000 to make two investments. She would like to invest US$ 850 to purchase a motorbike and a trailer for her husband to use to transport wood, and also put US$ 150 into her own food business, increasing the amount she can sell every day. She sees these investments as opportunities that will be able to increase her daily income.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and a trailer for wood transport

loans.name: Tun

texts.en: S. is 36 years old and a resident of Pursat Province. She makes a living raising pigs which she sells for slaughter in four months' time after raising. She has been raising pigs for 13 years and is currently earning around US$ 2.50 a day. S. is married with four children, all of whom are single. Her husband is Moun, aged 49, and he is a local rice farmer, a skill he learned from his parents. S. is applying for a loan as capital to allow her to save to help her husband to purchase a pair of buffalo to raise for sale, as well as using them for rice farming.

loans.use: To purchase a pair of buffalo to raise for sale

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica is engaged in the vending business.  She sells frozen food such as fish, meat and sausage wherein she earns PHP 600 a week. Due to increasing demand from her customers, she wantsto increase volume of products she sells.  This is the reason why she is asking for a loan of PHP 4,000 that she will invest in her business.  The amount will be of great help to Jessica in expanding her business.  

Patience and self confidence are some of the important things that she always keeps in mind in managing her business to succeed in life.

Jessica is married to Samuel, a welder in their village.  They have two children: Jimuel and Justin who are both in their elementary level.  The family lives in the village of Rizal, Santiago City, a rural area located four kilometers from the city proper.

loans.use: Invest in the vending business

loans.name: Luy

texts.en:
S. is 38 years old and a resident of Pursat Province. She earns a living by raising pigs in a stall next to her house. She raises two lots of pigs per year and sells them to the slaughterer every six months, and is earning an average of US$ 3 a day.

S. is married with two sons, who are still under her care. Her husband, Diem, age 48, is a local rice farmer. S. hopes to run a new suitable business; thus, she is applying for a loan to buy a motorbike that will be used to transport fish to sell at the market.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to transport fish

loans.name: Koch

texts.en: C., 24, has been raising pigs in a stall next to her house for a long time, and is earning an average of US$ 5 per day. She is married with three children. She currently lives in Pursat Province with her husband, who is a local farmer. C. hopes to have a rice-husking machine that would be a main source of additional income for family. Therefore, she is requesting a loan to add to her personal savings to purchase a rice-husking machine to provide a rice hulling service for villagers for a fee.

loans.use: To purchase a rice-hulling machine

loans.name: Men

texts.en: T. is 25 years old and a resident of Pursat Province where she owns a plot of land. She usually grows rice crops, which she plants twice a year, a skill she learned from her grandparents. She is a good mother to one child who is still young. T. is married to Mr. Sok, age 25, and he is working together with his wife, farming. To help do the hard physical labor with the farming business, T. is asking for a loan to buy a water buffalo to plow the field. (T.'s husband appears in the picture because she was not available.)

loans.use: To buy a water buffalo for plowing the field

loans.name: Farakhim

texts.en:
Farakhim M. is a 38-year-old trader who sells confections such as candies, chocolate, cookies and other items. He is married and has one adorable daughter who is the meaning of his life. 

Farakhim opened his store in 1999, when he could not find any job in his village and his family stayed without any means of subsistence. Farakhim would like to expand his business and purchase more confections for his store, to increase his income and improve life conditions for his family. For this purpose he applied for a loan of $1200 with 15 months for a term. Your generosity will be very helpful.

loans.use: Purchase confections to resell such as candies, chocolate, cookies and other items

loans.name: Ham

texts.en: S. is 40 years old and a resident of Banteay Meanchey Province, Cambodia, where she makes a living as an ox trader. She normally travels with her husband to buy cows from rural people and then fattens them a while and later on sells them to regular customers at a profit. She is married and the mother of two children; both of them are still young and go to school. The family's business is running very well and is profitable. To earn extra income, the family have decided to ask for a US$ 1,100 loan to buy more cows for re-sale. (S. was not available for photographing, so her husband is shown in the picture instead.)

loans.use: To buy more cows for sale

loans.name: Eldaniz

texts.en: Eldaniz A. is 33, single, and a young cattle breeder who lives in the small village of Imishli City with his parents who are on a pension now. He started animal breeding when he was a child because his father taught him. Eldaniz now is an experienced farmer whose dream is to build his own house and marry his fiancé. Eldaniz applied for $1200 to purchase two more calves and fodder.

loans.use: Purchase two more calves and fodder.

loans.name: Sarkhosh

texts.en: Sarkhosh M. is a 60-year-old trader who sells different kinds of food products. He is married and has six children. It is very hard to cover his family's needs with such a big family, but Sarkhosh does his best. He wakes up early in the morning and finishes his job late at night. His dream is to provide to the younger children with a good education. He applied for $1200 in a loan to increase the number of goods he sells. Let's help Sarkhosh and his big family!

loans.use: Purchase food products to resell

loans.name: Thai

texts.en: T., 49, has been selling vegetables in Mongkol Borey Market since 2002. She is married to Vann, 44, who has been a construction worker for a numbers of years. They live together  in a rural area of Banteay Meanchey Province, and they are responsible for three children; two of them are single and still live in the family home. T. is running the vegetable-selling business very well; she is skilled in communication in the market. To earn additional income, she is asking for a loan to buy different kinds of vegetables for re-sale.

loans.use: To buy different kinds of vegetables to sell

loans.name: Samaya

texts.en: Samaya A. is only 20, but she is already an independent young woman who struggles for a better future every moment of her life. After school she decided to enter to the university, but the sickness of her mother did not let her go. She decided to stay in her village and look after her mother. She decided to start her business and raise cattle for meat. Since 2002 Samaya has been buying, fattening and raising calves. She sells them to the local people and bazaar traders. Samaya now is ready to take a loan and continue expanding her business. For this purpose she applied for $1200 and is going to use it to purchase two baby calves and fodder. Samaya is counting on your help.

loans.use: Purchase two baby calves and fodder.

loans.name: Agamed

texts.en: Agamed A. is a 22-year-old man who sells different kinds of food products in the small village of Imishli City. He is not married yet, but his dream is to marry this year. Agamed started his business in 2003 to bring more income to his family, which consists of his parents and younger brothers and sisters. Agamed also works as a butcher in the local restaurant in the first part of the day, and from 12 p.m. until late night he works at his store. Now Agamed would like to increase his income and purchase more foodstuffs for his store.

loans.use: Purchase more foodstuffs for his store.

loans.name: Savun

texts.en:
Mrs. Savun S., 38, married her second husband in 2006. She has three children: one son and two daughters. Two of her children are garment factory workers and another one is still young. Besides her children she also has an elderly mother living with her. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number Five about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Savun has been growing lotus for two years, a skill she learned from her relative. She sells them in her village and at the market in Phnom Penh. Savun is requesting her first loan of US$ 500 to use for repairing her motorized hand tiller.

loans.use: To use for repairing her motorized hand tiller

loans.name: Moeurn

texts.en: S. is 45 years old and a resident of Battambang Province, Cambodia. She currently sells different varieties of fruit in the local market, and she can make about US$ 3 each day to support her family. She is married and has given birth to two children, both of whom are married and live away from the family home. Her husband's name is Chomreun, 44, and he is an electronics repairman, who sometime helps her sell fruit. S. hopes to have a cart so as to sell her fruit outside the market. Therefore, she is requesting a loan of US$ 500 to buy a cart to connect with her existing motorcycle to transport fruit to sell.

loans.use: To buy a cart to transport her fruit

loans.name: Savoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Savoeun H., 36, and her husband, Mr. Mao KH., 42, were married in 1989 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. One of their children has full-time employment, two children are in school and another one is still young. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number 5 about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia.

Savoeun has been selling and planting lotus fruit for over four years. She buys them from her villagers and sells them in the market at Phnom Penh. In addition to selling lotus fruit, she sells fish and grows rice as well. Her husband has been selling beef for three years. He buys cows and sells them to the slaughterhouse.

Savoeun is requesting her first loan of $1000 to purchase a trailer to connect to her motorized hand tiller for carrying rice.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer to connect to a motorized hand tiller

loans.name: Chann

texts.en:
Mrs. Chann L., 50, and her husband, Mr. Chamroeun Pha, 55, live along National Road Number One about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1979 and have seven children: six sons and one daughter. Three of their children have full-time employment and one son is married and lives outside the family home.
 
Chann has been selling grocery items for two years. She buys them from Koky market a bit far from her village and sells them at her house. Her husband has been farming for 30 years; it’s a skill he learned from his parents. Chann is requesting her first loan of $500 to purchase grocery items to sell.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items

loans.name: You's Group

texts.en:
This group of borrowers consists of four people, all of whom live in Prekpras Sdach Commune of Battambang Province. The group leader is L., 35, who earns a living by selling clothes in and around her community. She is married and has three children who are single and attend school. Her husband Viet, 44,  sells snooker equipment that he makes by himself. 

L. had been selling clothes since 2006, and she can earn about $3 a day. She buys the clothes in bulk and resells them in retail. Her work has improved her family's income. L. is seeking a loan to purchase additional clothes. 

The other three borrowers are:
T., who sells beef in the market, and she requests a loan to buy more beef.
S. L., who sells perfume in the market, and she asks for a loan to increase her inventory.
N., who is a teacher, and she is applying for a loan to pay her children's school fee.

loans.use: To purchase clothing

loans.name: Sakhay Dad

texts.en:
Sakhay Dad K.  lives in Kabul Afghanistan. He is  43 years old and is married with four children. Sakhay is a carpenter and needs money to enlarge his business. He has requested an individual loan of 50000 Afghani for a term of 11 months. He will use the loan to  buy necessary materials for his shop to complete his stock.
Sakhay is very happy with the loan process in Afghanistan that helps poor people in the country and he thanks they all lenders to AFSG, especially Kiva.

loans.use: To complete his stock and buy necessary materials for his shop

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester V. sells a variety of goods in her village where she owns a small store. She started her business in 1990 with capital of 2,000 pesos. She is now 54 and has two children. Her previous work was basket making, weaving and making good quality baskets to sell in the market. Now, she focuses her attention on her store. She uses the profit from selling a variety of goods to feed her family, send her children to school and pay their daily expenses.

Ester is asking CEVI for a loan of 8,000 pesos. She will use the loan to buy more merchandise for her store. This is one way she can attract more customers to her business. She dreams of having a bigger store someday and the loan she will receive will help a lot with her business expansion.

By joining in the CEVI credit program, Ester has access to credit assistance, trainings and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Nonata

texts.en:
Nonata S. owns a small sari sari store. Why "sari-sari"? Because it is the Filipino local term for "variety" or "sundry shop". She sells dry goods, soaps, vinegars, rice, shampoo and other products in her village. People come in to buy their needs. Nonata is 27 years old and married to Julito S.. They have one child. She previously worked as an Avon lady, a person who sells Avon fashion products.

Nonata is requesting a loan of 11,000 pesos from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy more goods for her store. In this way, she believes she will attract more customers. Her loan will be a big help in her business expansion. Her business feeds her family. She needs to sustain it more for the future of her family.

CEVI is helping its clients sustain and expand their businesses. All CEVI clients receive credit assistance, trainings and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To purchase goods for her store.

loans.name: Khanam Gull Group

texts.en:
Khanam Gull is the group leader of the Zaya Jan group. They live in district 10 of Kabul Afghanistan. There are two members in this group and each of them would like to take a loan for their own business. 
Khanam Gull wants to take the loan for her husband’s business of general store   he wants to buy necessary material for his shop. And Hanefa wants to take a loan for his husband’s business of of taxi driver. He is working seven days a week to develop his business and cover his families expanses. They want to progress their business and to have a high monthly income to support their families in a better way.

loans.use: their very happy with this loan

loans.name: Shamim Qadir Muhammad Group

texts.en:
Shamim baji is 53 years old. She has lived in Pakpattan, Pakistan for 20 years. Her husband, Q. M., runs a grocery store in the community. Shamim baji is the mother of two sons. Her elder son works in a decorative embroider business and her younger son is a welder. She is applying for a loan to buy groceries to diversify her husband’s grocery store.

Shamim baji is the group leader. The others in her group are:
Ameena baji, who wants a loan to buy leather to sell. 
Iram baji, who wants a loan to buy paint to sell. 
Ameeran baji, who wants a loan to buy thread to sell. 
Hamidan baji and Shahnaz baji, who each want a loan to buy beams for their shuttering businesses. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries

loans.name: Sheema Gulzar Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Sheema baji, 43, is married and has lived in Pakpattan, Pakistan for eight years. Pakpattan is famous for its shrines. People used to come to this city to visit these shrines. Sheema baji's husband is G. A.. He is a wholesaler by profession. He buys different items wholesale and sells to different places and shops. They have one daughter. Sheema baji is very concerned about her daughter, and wants to do whatever she can to provide her daughter with a happy life.  Sheema baji embroiders dresses and sews clothes. She invests her amount in a committee and wants to marry off her daughter when she gets the whole amount. She has successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy wheat to sell.

Sheema baji is a group leader. The other women in her group are:
G. sakina baji, who wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her fruit selling business. 
Manzooran baji, who wants a loan to buy wheat to sell. 
Mumtaz baji, who wants a loan to buy plastic beans to make plastic bottles. 
Nusrat baji, who wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).  

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy wheat

loans.name: Azra Shahzad Sarwar Group
loans.use: To buy materials for making shoes.

loans.name: Sayyan Zakir Hussain Group

texts.en:
Sayyan baji is 33 years old and a married lady and citizen of a city called Pakpattan, Pakistan for the past 20 years. Her husband's name is Z. H. and he is a mason by trade. Sayyan baji is the mother of four kids: three daughters and one son. All of her kids are getting an education from a school which is near their house.

Sayyan baji is a very hard-working lady. She believes in hard work. She is involved in an embroidery business. She prepares embroidered dresses to order and charges US$ 3 for per embroidered dress. She does this work to pay the school fees of her kids, because her husband’s income is very small. She is applying for a loan to buy mason's tools for her husband.

She is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Ishrat baji wants a loan to buy vegetables for her vegetable-selling business. Shamim baji and another Shamim baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shops. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruit to sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy mason's tools

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
“Hard work and patience are virtues one needs to become a successful entrepreneur” said Marites D., a micro- entrepreneur living in the village of Rizal, Santiago City.  

Marites operates her gown rental and catering businesses. Aside from these, she also sells frozen foods in their village for extra income to support the education of their children especially that her eldest child is about to entercollege this school year.  Her weekly income is carefully budgeted for their daily needs, school allowance and working capital for her businesses.  She wants to improve and develop her businesses for her family. For her gown rental business, she wants to avail a loan of PHP5,000.  She believes that to become successful, she needs to trust in her own ability and have faith in God.  

Her husband Jimmy is engaged in farming.  Their children are: Zyrene Andrella,16, a senior high school student and Wyndie Reeze,12, a graduating elementary student.

loans.use: Additional working capital for her business

loans.name: Chhum's Group

texts.en:
There are four people who form this small loan group, residents of Battambang Province, Cambodia. N. has been selected to be group leader by the members. N., 48, currently lives with her four children, all of them students. She is a vegetable seller, selling apples, grapes, melons, and peaches etc., earning approximately US$ 5 per day.

N. is married to Mr. Samout, 49, who is a Khmer traditional music player for wedding parties in the village. N. runs her fruit stand, selling early morning and finishing in the evening to help earn their living. Currently, she sold all her fruit from her store and she needed to buy more fruit to sell, that’s why she requested the loan.

The other three borrowers are:

M., a local tailor, who is requesting a loan for her husband's farming business activities;

N., a grocer and a widow, asking for a loan to enlarge her business; and

C. E. who sells sugar cane juice and needs a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more fruit to sell

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en:
Rukia has been a firewood and cloth ("khanga"--traditional Tanzanian fabric worn by women--and bedsheets) seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 2 years. She belongs to "Maisha bora" loan group. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 20. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more firewood, "khanga" and bedsheets for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money.

Rukia is 23 years old, married, and has one child, age 2.

loans.use: To buy more firewood, "khanga" and bedsheets to expand her business

loans.name: Nuru Njema Group

texts.en:
Husna has been a firewood, perfume and juice seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 2 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 125. Every day she works at her business for 14 hours. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more firewood, perfume, and juice for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and to save money for future use.

Husna is 26 years old, married, and has two children: ages 5 and 1. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Amina and Asha. Each woman has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more firewood, perfume, and juice for her business

loans.name: Thuy Thi's Group

texts.vi:
Nguyễn Thị Thuỷ sinh năm 1976,(Mã số: 010117140007). Chị bán hang giải khát ( nước ngọt, bánh kẹo,…). Chồng chị làm công nhân có thu nhập ône định. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 2.000.000 vnđ /tháng. Chị tham gia vay vốn mức: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư bán hàng. Chị là nhóm trưởng nhóm vay vốn gồm có:
 Lê Phương A. sinh năm 1977, (Mã số: 010117140008).  làm nghề thợ may, chồng chị làm tai công ty sữa có thu nhập ổn định. Chị vay mức vốn vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để mua vải mở rộng cửa hàng may mặc.
  Trần Thị Thuý Hà sinh năm 1980. (Mã số: 010117140009).  Chị là giáo viên, chồng là thợ sửa chữa ô tô, có thu nhập ổn định. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng: 3.000.000 vnđ/tháng. Chị vay mức vốn vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để mở xưởng sửa chữa xe.
Nguyễn Thị Năng sinh năm 1963, (Mã số: 010117140010). chị chủ yếu làm nông nghiệp, làm vườn, bán rau. Chồng chị làm bảo vệ trông trường học, hai con chị còn nhỏ đang độ tuổi đi học. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình khoảng 300.000 vnđ/tuần. Chị vay mức vốn: 4.142.000 vnđ để mua phân bón.
 Nguyễn Thị Thuận sinh năm 1958, (Mã số: 010117140011).  làm nông nghiệp , chăn nuôi. Chồng chị làm thuê và phụ giúp chị công bviệc đồng áng và đi đánh cá về bán. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng: 250.000 vnđ/tuần. Chị vay mức vốn: 4.142.000 vnđ để đi chợ.
texts.en:
Mrs. T. T. N. was born in 1976. She sells beverages such as sodas and candies. Her husband is a laborer with a stable income. The family's average income is about 2,000,000 VND per month. She joined the Fund with a loan of 4,142,000 VND to invest in her beverage sales business. She is the group leader for this group loan, which also includes: - Mrs. A. P. Le, born in 1977, is a tailor. Her husband works at a milk factory with a stable income. She is borrowing 4,142,000 VND to buy fabric to expand her tailoring business. - Mrs. T. T. Tran, born in 1980, is a teacher. Her husband is a car mechanic with a stable income. Her family's average income is around 3,000,000 VND per month. She is borrowing 4,142,000 VND to help her husband open an auto mechanic's shop. - Mrs. N. T. N., born 1963, works mainly agricultural jobs, including landscaping and selling vegetables. Her husband is a security guard at a school, and her two small children attend school. The family's average income is about 300,000 VND per week. She is borrowing 4,142,000 VND to buy fertilizer. - Mrs. T. T. N., born in 1958, works in agriculture and raising livestock. Her husband works as labor for hire, helps her in the field, and works as a fisherman as well. Their average income is around 250,000 VND per week. She is borrowing 4,142,000 VND to trade goods.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi N., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: various small businesses

loans.name: Tupendane Group

texts.en:
Asha has been a coconut and bites seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 4 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 125. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more coconuts for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

Asha is 36 years old, married, and has eight children: ages 19, 18, 16, 15, 11, 7, 2, and 2 months. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member Mariam, who has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more coconuts in order to expand her business

loans.name: Nghe Thi

texts.vi: Đỗ Thị Nghê sinh năm 1959, ( Mã số: 010117140034 ) Chồng chị đã chết, hiện chị đang sống cùng cháu tại thôn Đài Bi- Uy Nỗ- Đông Anh- Hà Nội. Chị bán hàng nước, hàng ăn sáng( phở, bún,…) Thu nhập bình quân của chị khoảng 200.000 vnđ/ tuần. Đây là lần đầu tiên chị tham gia vay vốn nên chị chỉ tham gia nở mức vay: 1.972.000 vn đ để dầu tư thêm hàng bán quán của mình. Chị cố gắng hoàn trả đầy đủ để ngày càng được vay cao hơn cải thiện kinh tế của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nghe Thi D. was born in 1959. Her husband has passed, and she is currently living with a nephew or niece in the town of Dai Bi, Uy No, Dong Anh, Ha Noi. She runs a stand selling beverages, breakfast foods (beef noodle, vermicelli rice bowls, etc.) Her family's average income is 200,000 VND per week. This is her first time participating in the Fund so she is borrowing 1,972,000 VND to invest in her food stand. She will work very hard to repay the loan in full in order to be able to borrow larger amounts to improve her family's quality of life.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: food stand

loans.name: M'mola Group

texts.en:
Mwaka owns a small charcoal store and also sells coconuts in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar. She has been in business for 10 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $125. She works 14 hours a day and she is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal and coconuts for her business. She is hopping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money.  

Mwaka is 45 years old, widowed, and has eight children. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Fatma, Rehema M. and Rehema R.. Each woman also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and coconuts for her business.

loans.name: Allan

texts.en:
Allan B. is a rice grower. He is 39 years old and has two children. He used to be a security officer, but he was not happy about guarding office premises because of the low income he got from his job. He started tilling their small parcel of land to support the needs of his children. His family gave him a share of two hectares of rice field. From then, he started to manage the land, grow some crops and make it sustainable. He uses his harvest to feed his family and to earn a little income from selling rice to the villagers.

Allan is asking for a loan of 10,000 pesos to grow more rice. He will use the loan to buy fertilizers including two bags of urea, triple 14, 21-0-0, 1 quart trebon, 1 box mipcin, 2 quarts 2 4 D, Hostathion, and Bushwack. The fertilizers will definitely give him a bigger and better harvest.

Because he is a CEVI client, Allan has access to the CEVI credit program, trainings and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers, insecticides and other farm chemicals.

loans.name: Dolgor

texts.en: Dolgor T. is a married young woman who lives with her husband and daughter in the center of Uvurhangai province. Uvurhangai is a one of Mongolia's southern provinces, locates 400 km from the capital city, Ulaanbaatar, and not too far from the Chinese border. Dolgor's family lives in her father in-law's yard located in a "ger" district (a ger is the traditional, nomadic form of housing in Mongolia; a ger district is where many people have settled in these homes, forming a sort of ad hoc suburb). Though they rent the land on which they set up their ger, they own the get itself. Dolgor graduated high school several years ago. After her graduation, she moved to countryside to become a herder. In 2006 she moved back to center of her province to run a retail sales business. When she begun her business she buy many small goods from others and sell them back. To expand her business, she has bought a stall last year. Now she is running her retail sales business with her husband. They sell mostly women clothes such as sweaters, blouses and jeans. But they also sell small items such as jewelry (fake), socks and so on. She or her husband goes to Ereen, a city just across the Chinese border, once or twice a month to buy goods for the business. With the lunar New Year celebration approaching, small items have sold quickly, therefore, they wants a loan to buy more small items.

loans.use: To buy small items for lunar new year sales

loans.name: Ngoc Thi's Group

texts.vi:
P. Thị Ngọc sinh năm 1953 ( Mã số: 010117140030 ) . Chồng chị đã chết, chị hiện đang sống cùng con gái đã đi làm nên có thu nhập hỗ trợ chị. Hàng ngày, chị đi bán rau ở chợ đồng thời tăng gia sản xuất. Thu nhập bình quân của mẹ con chị khoảng 250.000 vnđ/tuần. Chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 5014000 vnđ để mua giống cây trồng và đi chợ. chị là nhóm trưởng nhóm vay vốn gồm có:
 Phạm thị Tuyết L. sinh năm 1973, ( Mã số: 010117140029 )  Chị bán hàng thực phẩm( gà, vịt quay chin,,,)gia đình chị có thu nhập ổn định trung bình khoảng:350.000 vnđ/tuần. Chị vay mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư cửa hàng.
 Cao Thị Thuần sinh năm 1971, ( Mã số: 010117140031 )  chồng chị làm nghề thợ mộc, bản thân chị bán trứng vịt có thu nhập theo ngày. Thu nhập binh quân của gia đình chị khoảng:300.000 vnđ/ tuần.Chị vay vốn mức vay: 4.578.000 vnđ để có vốn mua trứng về bán.
Nguyễn Thị Hồng sinh năm 1951, ( Mã số: 010117140032 )  gia đình chị có vườn cây ăn quả(cam, quýt, táo,..). Chồng chị có lương ổn định theo tháng( lương hưu), Chị vay vốn mức: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư vườn cây ăn quả và đi chợ.
 Nguyễn Bích Phương sinh năm 1974, ( Mã số: 010117140033)  chị bán hàng quần áo ở chợ, chồng chị làm công nhân, có thu  nhập ổn định theo tháng, thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 3.000.000 vnđ/tháng. Chị vay mức vốn: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư mở rộng hàng quần áo.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ngoc T. P. was born in 1953. Her husband has passed, and she is currently living with her adult daughter. Her daughter is already working so she has some income to support her mother. Everyday, Mrs. P. sells vegetables at the market while working other jobs on the side. The family's average income is around 250,000 VND per week. She joined the Fund with a loan of 5,014,000 VND to buy seedlings to plant and to trade goods. She is the group leader for this group loan, which also includes: - Mrs. T. T. Pham, born in 1973. She sells various foods (chicken, roast duck, etc.). Her family has a stable income at around 350,000 VND per week. She is borrowing 4,142,000 VND to invest in her store. - Mrs. T. T. Cao, born in 1971. Her husband works as a woodcarver, while she sells duck eggs with a variable daily income. The family's average income is 300,000 VND per week. She is borrowing 4,578,000 VND to buy eggs to sell. - Mrs. H. T. Nguyen was born in 1951. Her family has a fruit orchard (oranges, tangerines, apples, etc.). Her husband has a stable income from his pension. She is borrowing 4,142,000 VND to invest in the orchard and to trade goods. - Mrs. P. B. Nguyen was born in 1974. She sells clothes at the market, and her husband is laborer with a stable monthly income. The family's average income is around 3,000,000 VND per month. She is borrowing 4,142,000 VND to invest in expanding her clothing sales.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sales at the market, fruit orchard

loans.name: Hok

texts.en: N. is a 40 year old resident of Kompong Tom Province in Cambodia, where she owns a stall behind her house raising pigs for sale. For her other income, she also cultivates rice, and she has don both of these businesses for more than four years. She is married and is the mother of one child who is a lovely young daughter, and is enrolled in the local school. Her husband is a charcoal seller. In the past, N. usually hires a farm land from a villager for her rice farming. She now hopes to own a farm land; thus, she would like to ask for a loan to purchase a plot of farm land.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of farmland

loans.name: Hatuyumbishwi Group

texts.en:
Biha is a food (bread and juice) seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 20 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of 125 dollars, working 12 hours a day. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more bread and juice for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, save money, and pay school fees for her children.  

Biha is 50 years old, married, and has three children: ages 19, 17 and 6. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Mwanaid, who also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more food items (breads and juice) for her business.

loans.name: Tusaidiane Group

texts.en:
Pili is 29 years old, and married. She also takes care of another family member in her home. Pili has operated her own small restaurant and has also sold clothing in the local Mikunguni neighborhood for the past four years. She earns a monthly profit of around $175, by working daily for fourteen hours. She is currently requesting a loan to increase her inventory, to expand her store and explore the possibility of opening a new one. She is hoping that through this loan, she can boost her profits and save enough money for future use.

Pili will also share this loan with her fellow group members, Asia, Zukelkha, Zuwena, and Khadija. Each of these women owns their own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To increase her inventory and to open a new shop.

loans.name: Nguyen's Group

texts.vi:
Nguyễn Thị L. sinh năm 1979, ( mã số: 010117140035)  chị bán hàng quần áo, bán vải ở chợ có thu nhập theo ngày. Chồng chị làm thợ xây, hai con còn nhỏ đang độ tuổi đi học. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 300.000 vn đ/ tuần. Ngoài ra, vợ chồng chị vẫn chăn nuôi để tăng thu nhập. Chị tham gia vay vốn với mức vay: 4.142.000 vn đ để đi chợ và chăn nuôi lợn. Chị là nhóm trưởng nhóm vay vốn gồm có:
 Đỗ D. Phấn sinh năm 1983 , ( mã số: 010117140036) Anh là công nhân có thu nhập ổn định theo tháng, vợ anh đi chợ có thu nhập theo ngày. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng: 300.000 vn đ/ tuần. Gia đình vay vốn để đầu tư đi chợ với mức vay: 3.270.000 vn đ.
  Nguyễn Thị Vân sinh năm 1961.  ( mã số: 010117140037) Gia đình chị chủ yếu làm nông nghiệp và chăn nuôi. Chị cũng đi chợ buôn bán nhỏ để tăng thu nhập, con trai chị cũng đi làm có thu nhập phụ giúp kinh tế cho gia đình. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 350.000 vn đ/tuần. Chị vay mức vốn: 3.270.000 vn đ để chăn nuôi.
 Đỗ Thị Liên sinh năm 1956, ( mã số: 010117140038). chồng chị đã mất, chị ở với vợ chồng người con trai. Chị vay mức vốn vay: 3.270.000 vn đ để đầu tư mở cửa hàng buôn bán nhỏ tại nhà.
  Hoàng Thị Hà sinh năm 1979, ( mã số: 01011714003), Vợ chồng chị có xưởng làm cửa nhom kính tại nhà. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 300.000  vn đ /tuần. Chị vay: 5.014.000 VND để đầu tư cửa hàng của gia đình.
texts.en:
Nguyễn Thị L. sinh năm 1979, ( mã số: 010117140035) chị bán hàng quần áo, bán vải ở chợ có thu nhập theo ngày. Chồng chị làm thợ xây, hai con còn nhỏ đang độ tuổi đi học. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 300.000 vn đ/ tuần. Ngoài ra, vợ chồng chị vẫn chăn nuôi để tăng thu nhập. Chị tham gia vay vốn với mức vay: 4.142.000 vn đ để đi chợ và chăn nuôi lợn. Chị là nhóm trưởng nhóm vay vốn gồm có: Đỗ D. Phấn sinh năm 1983 , ( mã số: 010117140036) Anh là công nhân có thu nhập ổn định theo tháng, vợ anh đi chợ có thu nhập theo ngày. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng: 300.000 vn đ/ tuần. Gia đình vay vốn để đầu tư đi chợ với mức vay: 3.270.000 vn đ. Nguyễn Thị Vân sinh năm 1961. ( mã số: 010117140037) Gia đình chị chủ yếu làm nông nghiệp và chăn nuôi. Chị cũng đi chợ buôn bán nhỏ để tăng thu nhập, con trai chị cũng đi làm có thu nhập phụ giúp kinh tế cho gia đình. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 350.000 vn đ/tuần. Chị vay mức vốn: 3.270.000 vn đ để chăn nuôi. Đỗ Thị Liên sinh năm 1956, ( mã số: 010117140038). chồng chị đã mất, chị ở với vợ chồng người con trai. Chị vay mức vốn vay: 3.270.000 vn đ để đầu tư mở cửa hàng buôn bán nhỏ tại nhà. Hoàng Thị Hà sinh năm 1979, ( mã số: 01011714003), Vợ chồng chị có xưởng làm cửa nhom kính tại nhà. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 300.000 vn đ /tuần. Chị vay vốn để đầu tư cửa hàng của gia đình.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: đi chợ

loans.name: Semeni

texts.en: Semeni is a snack seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood in Zanzibar.  Semeni is 28 years old,  is married, and has two children ages 12 and 5.   She belongs to Wachawaseme loan group (Group code 2061).  She works for 6 hours everyday.  This is her second loan from BRAC Tanzania.  She plans to use it to buy more items for her business. She is hoping that with this loan she will be able to grow her business and reinvest some of her profits for future growth.

loans.use: To buy more items inorder to expand her business.

loans.name: Rogelia

texts.en: Rogelia, 43, is blessed with 8 children, all of whom are in school. She strives hard to provide the immediate needs of her family and to help out her husband who used to be the sole provider of the family through farming. Farming in the Philippines is not lucrative due to inadequate technology. Therefore, Rogelia decided to open a small variety store to supplement the family income. She has worked hard to build a successful business, and a loyal network of customers. She joined HSPFI and is now requesting a 8000 PHP loan to increase her inventory.

loans.use: To increase inventory

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Mornh

texts.en: Mr. O. is 58 years old and is married with five children, three of which are single and two of which are married. To help meet the family's needs, three of his children are employed, two as garment workers and one as a local carpenter, His wife is named VO. and is 50 years old. The couple currently grows potato, which they will sell once they have matured. They have been running the business for more than four years, a trade passed down from their grandparents. The family's living conditions are not very good because their house needs repairs. Therefore, O. is asking for a $1000 loan to add to his personal savings to repair their old house. (O.'s wife is pictured.)

loans.use: To build a new house

loans.name: Novie

texts.en:
Novie M., 37 years old, grows rice on her farm. Joel M., her husband, is the one who manages their farm. They work very hard to increase their yield to support their family, especially now that both of their children are going to school. Three years ago, Novie inherited one hectare of land from her parents. That is what they use to feed their children, pay their daily expenses and pay tuition fees and other bills. Novie previously worked in a canning factory but she was not so happy about it.

Novie is asking for a loan from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers, specifically two bags of urea. She will also buy three sacks of quality rice seeds. She is also considering looking for some other possible income areas to help her family more.

Novie has access to CEVI credit assistance. She also receives relevant trainings and insurance coverage from CEVI.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and seed.

loans.name: Art

texts.en: Art S., 38, is married and lives with three of her children in the Siem Reap province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about US $2.50 each day. The weather conditions and inflation most negatively impact her business. The domestic price of rice and fertilizers has doubled over the past year, while the price of meat and fish has increased 30 to 60 percent, according to the a recent government report. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, including Art S.. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase fertilizer and rice seed to expand her cultivation. The rest of the loan will be used to repair her leaking house. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and rice seed and repair her leaky roof.

loans.name: Sann

texts.en: Sann S., 28, is married and lives with her one child in the Siem Reap province. She works in a grocery store, making around US$3 each day, while her husband works as a barber. Her husband makes about US$5 each day. Food prices have soared in the past year as inflation has gotten out of control in Cambodia. Unfavorable climate conditions have also played a factor in making the price of rice very high. Sann S. is asking for a loan of US$1000 to expand her grocery store by adding more products to meet her client’s demand. She is confident that this will be a good business venture and sees it as a tool to increase her income and raise her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To expand her grocery store.

loans.name: Mwanahamis

texts.en: Mwanahamis is 40 years old, married, and has nine children. She currently sells food in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar. Her current average monthly profit is around $250, which she earns by working at her business for around 14 hours a day. This is her first loan from BRAC Tanzania, and she is hoping to increase her profit margin and also expand her business. She will in turn use her income to provide her children with the education they need to succeed.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Lux

texts.en: Lux S. is 22 years old and lives with her husband in the Siem Reap province. She stays at home and raises pigs to earn approximately $1 every day, while her husband works as a fisherman. He catches and sells fish to the market-seller, earning around $4 per day. This couple has two young children. Mrs. Lux S. is asking for a loan to purchase fishing nets for her husband and increase her livestock by adding more pigs.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets and raise pigs.

loans.name: Munhtuul

texts.en: Munhtuul A. is a single mother with one daughter. They live with her parents, both of whom are retired. Her daughter is 15 and goes to high school. To feed her family, Munhtuul runs a retail business, selling "huurug" (a traditional Mongolian snuff case that is popular with well-to-do men made from semi-precious stones, with a band of gold or silver under the cap) at Narantuul, the biggest outdoor market in Mongolia. Her sister and brother-in-law help with her business. When she started the business, she would hire someone to travel to the Chinese border city of Ereen to buy the huurug containers in bulk, and would make the caps herself out of coral. These days, she goes to Ereen herself to buy huurug. Her dream is to establish her own huurug factory -- the first ever in Mongolia! Nowadays, she is working to expand her home workshop with her business profit. The loan she is requesting is to purchase huurug to increase her business inventory. She has taken loans from XacBank (Kiva's partner microfinance institution in Mongolia) three times before to expand her business. She has a very good credit history with the bank.  In the picture, she stands on the right.

loans.use: To purchase "huurug" snuff bottles.

loans.name: Mok

texts.en: Mok M. is 30 years old. Mok has three children and lives in the Siem Reap province with her husband. She grows rice and her husband fishes. Mok M. is asking for a loan of US$400 to purchase wooden boat and fishing tools. She believes this will help expand her business and grow future profits.

loans.use: To purchase wooden boat and fishing tools.

loans.name: Wachewaseme Group

texts.en: Sharifa is 30 years old, married, and has two children: ages 7 and 4. Sharifa is currently a clothes saleswoman who has been living in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 2 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $125 and works a daily shift of 12 hours.  She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can purchase more clothes and restock her business, and she is hopping that with this loan she will increase her profit.  She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Fatma and Mwajuma. Each woman also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Luk

texts.en: Luk Y. is 35 years old and lives with her husband in Siem Reap, Cambodia. She has made and sold charcoal since 2003. On average, she makes US$5 a day and her husband earns about US$3 a day cultivating rice. This couple has five children, three of whom attend school. Mrs. Luk Y. would like to take out a loan to purchase a small truck to transport her charcoal to sell in the market province.

loans.use: To purchase a small truck.

loans.name: Sam

texts.en: Sam Y. was born in 1958 and runs a medium-sized farmland for growing potatoes. He started in the business with his wife in 2000, and they make around of $5 per day from his investment. They both live with three children who have left school and who help with their parents' business activities. They together reside in the rural area of Kompong Tom Province, Cambodia. Y. is applying for a loan as capital to start a new investment by buying beds to store and later to re-sell for a profit. The loan will allow them another income for the family's living. (Y.'s wife is pictured.)

loans.use: To purchase beds for resale.

loans.name: Zahira

texts.en:
Zahira has owned a small restaurant and shop in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for the last 5 years. 
She belongs to Tusaidiane loan group (Group code 2019).Every day she works at her business for 14 hours.  She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items for her business. She is hopping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.  

Zahira is 28 years old, married, and has 1 child aged 3.

loans.use: To buy more items for her shop and restaurant

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy merchandise for resale

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a fashion designer and she also sells tailoring materials. She has been in this business for the past eight years. In her community, she is the only person selling tailoring materials. Hence the demands for her goods are high. She needs the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. Mary is 27 years old and married with a child. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Dousoussouma Group

texts.fr:
Les dix femmes du groupe Dousoussouma sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 38ans et 5 enfants et ont toutes des coépouses. Elles vivent dans le village de TDJILA, sous préfecture de NIENA de la 3ème région administrative du Mali.
 Elles font le commerce d’articles divers tels la vente de soumbala, de condiments alimentaires, d’arachide, des légumes et la restauration.
Elles sont à leur première prêt (prêt solidaire) et comptent l’utiliser pour acheter,  7 sacs de céréales et d’arachide, 100 kilogrammes de grains de Néré pour faire le soumbala, 5 sacs de légumes et divers  condiments. Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de NIENA, et de TDJILA. Les marchandises sont vendues en détail et au comptant au marché de NIENA, de BOUGOULABA et celui de NIEN à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 5000FCFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie  investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The ten women in the Dousoussouma group are all married and have co-spouses. They average 38 years of age and 5 children. They live in the village of Tdjila, in the Niena subprefecture, third administrative region of Mali.
