Their businesses consist in selling diverse items such as soumbala (a traditional condiment made out of Néré seeds), food condiments, peanuts, vegetables, as well as in food serving.

They are seeking their first group loan (solidarity loan) and intend to use it to buy 7 sacks of cereals and peanuts, 100 kilograms of Néré seeds to make soumbala, 5 sacks of vegetables and various condiments. The get their supplies at the Niena and Tdjila markets. The goods are retailed for cash at the Niena, Bougoulaba and Nien markets, to a clientele comprising men and women.

They foresee to turn a monthly profit of XOF 5'000 (ca US$ 10) each, to be in part used to provide for their families, and in part invested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell various items (cereals, peanuts, vegetables, ...)

loans.name: Mkasi

texts.en:
Mkasi has owned a small firewood store in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 2 years. She belongs to Sisi kwasisi loan group (Group code 2023).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $50.Every day she works at her business for 14 hours.  She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more firewood for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, pay school fees for her children and save money for future use.  

Mkasi is 40 years old, married, and has three children: ages 14, 11 and 6.

loans.use: To buy more firewood for her business.

loans.name: Joke

texts.en: Joke is a mother of four. She is 35 years old and married. She lives in Ipaja, Lagos state, Nigeria. Joke sells cooked foods and her restaurant is very popular within her community. She also sells drinks and bottled water. She has been in this business for the past five years. She needs the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell to her customers. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Orn

texts.en: S. is 30 years old a resident of Kompong Tom Province, Cambodia, where she runs a stall raising pigs. For additional income, she also grows rice crops, which she can plant twice per year, once during the rainy season and once during the dry season. S. is married and has no child. Her husband’s name is Troeung, is aged 31, and he works sawing wood and harvesting rice for income. S. is seeking a loan to buy water buffalo to be used to plow a farmland and the future for offspring.

loans.use: To buy water buffalo for plowing her field.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam has been a bread seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 2 years. She belongs to A'Mola loan group (Group code 2039).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $250. Every day she works at her business for 14 hours.  She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more bread for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and to save money for future use.  

Mariam is 24 years old, married, and has one child: aged 10 months.

loans.use: To buy more breads for her business.

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en: Pamela owns a boutique where she sells children's clothes, ladies shoes, and handbags. Pamela is 37-years old and married with three children. Pamela is requesting a loan to increase her inventory and expand her business. She says thank you, and she looks forward to earning a better income for her family.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes, hand bags and shoes to expand business

loans.name: Jiguiseme Group

texts.fr:
Les dix femmes du groupe Jiguisseme sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des  familles traditionnelles polygames en majorité, à TDJILAI situé dans la sous préfecture de NIENA de la 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles menent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres l’achat - vente de céréales, de condiments alimentaires et de canaris. Elles sont à leur premier prêt (prêt solidaire). 
Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt, 10sacs de 100kg de céréales, 15 canaris et divers condiments .Elles s’approvisionnent  au marché de NIENA, de BOUGOULABA et de TDJILA.. Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de NIENA, de BOUGOULABA, de TDJILA et de TIENKOUNKO en détail et au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 7 500FCFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie  investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The ten women in the group Jiguisseme are all married and average 38 years of age and 4 children. Most of them live in traditional polygamous families in Tdjilai, located in the subprefecture of Niena in the third administrative region of Mali. They run various businesses, such as : buying and selling cereals, food condiments, and "canaris" (food containers). They are seeking their first group loan (solidarity loan). They intend to use it to buy 10 100-kilogram sacks of cereals, 15 "canaris", and various food condiments. They get their supplies at the Niéna, Bougoulaba and Tdjila markets. The goods are retailed for cash at the Niéna, Bougoulaba, Tdjila and Tienkounko markets, to a clientele comprising men and women. They intend to turn an average monthly profit of XOF 7'500 each (ca US$15), to be in part used to provide for the family expenses, and in part invested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell various items (cereals, food condiments, ...)

loans.name: Tuyet Thi's Group

texts.vi:
Đinh Thị Tuyết sinh năm 1962.( Mã số: 010105030036  )  Gia đình chị có cửa hàng giải khát( bán bia, nước mía,…) và có nghề phụ: làm chổi. Vợ chồng chị có ba người con đã lớn phần nào phụ giúp công việc gia đình cho bố mẹ. Thu nhập theo ngày từ bán hàng và tiền công làm thuê đem lại khoảng 4.000.000 vn đ/ tháng cho gia đình chị. Chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 2.436.000 vn đ để đầu tư vào cửa hàng. Chị là nhóm trưởng nhóm vay vốn gồm có:
 Chu Thị Bích sinh năm 1974 .( Mã số: 010105030039 ) Chồng chị làm thợ xây, gia đình chủ yếu vẫn làm nông nghiệp. thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng:2.500.000 vnd /tháng. Chị vay vốn mức vay: 2.436.000 vnd để đi chợ.
 Nguyễn Thị Khánh Hồng sinh năm 1952, ( Mã số: 010105030040 ) hàng ngày chị đi chợ bán hàng khô, có thu nhập theo ngày khoảng 100.000 vnd/ngày. Chị vay mức vốn: 2.436.000 vnd để mua hàng hóa về bán.
 Chử Thị Vân sinh năm 1966, ( Mã số: 010105030038 ) chị có nghề làm chổi có thu nhập. chị vay mức vốn: 2.436.000 vn đ để mua nguyên vật lieuj về làm chổi.
 Nguyễn Thị L. sinh năm 1957, ( Mã số: 010105030037 ) chị là giáo viên mầm non, có thu nhập ổn định. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng: 3.000.000 vn đ/tháng. Chị tham gia vay vốn mức ; 2.900.000 vn đ để chăn nuôi lợn.
texts.en:
Mrs. Tuyet T. D., 47 years old, SEDA ID# 010105030036. Her family owns a beverage store and make and sell brooms for extra money. The couple has three children, who are able to help with housework. The family’s income is about 4,000,000 VND per month. She wants to borrow 2,436,000 VND to invest in the store. She is the leader of the group of following persons: Mrs. B. T. Chu, 35 years old, SEDA ID# 010105030039. Her husband is a construction worker, when she works on her family’s field. The family’s income is about 2,500,000 VND per month. She borrows 2,436,000 VND for personal use. Mrs. H. T. K. Nguyen, 57 years old, SEDA ID#010105030040. She sells dried food in the local market, earning about 100,000 VND per day. She borrows 2,436,000 VND to buy more inventory. Mrs. V. T. Chu, 43 years old, SEDA ID# 010105030038. She makes and sells brooms. She borrows 2,436,000 VND to buy raw material. Mrs. L. T. Nguyen, 52 years old, SEDA ID#010105030037. She is a teacher in the local kindergarten and has stable income. Her family’s income is about 3,000,000 VND per moth. She borrows 2,900,000 VND to raise pigs.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy inventory, raw material, and some personal use

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace O. recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya.

As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin-enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

Grace is 34 years old and a widow. She has 2 children, a girl and a boy, who are both in school. She heard about K-MET from friends and decided that she wanted to join and be trained to work in the community.

Grace has worked in salons for 9 years. She was interested and the practice was easy for her, so in 2002 she took a stylist course in Kisumu in order to get more qualifications. In 2006 Grace started her own salon in the Nyalenda area of Kisumu. She employs one other woman to work in the salon.

This will be Grace’s first loan from K-MET. She has applied for approximately $200 and will use the loan to buy chemicals, hair pieces, weaves, shampoo, and conditioner.

loans.use: To purchase hair products

loans.name: Maryam

texts.en:
Maryam has owned a small shop and has been a food seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 4 years. 
She belongs to Bahati loan group (Group code 2019).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $250.Every day she works at her business for 14 hours.  She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items and other shop items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.  

Maryam is 26 years old, married, and has one child: aged 4.

loans.use: To buy more food items and other items for her shop in order to expand her business.

loans.name: Sally

texts.en: Sally is a determined mother of 3 children and a compassionate wife to a sick husband. She never loses hopes and works hard to support her family. She manages a variety store and twice a week has to wake-up as early as 3 o'clock in the morning to buy inventory for her variety store as the market is 67 kms. from her home. Starting with a small capital of PHP 5000 obtained from a loan with HSPFI, Sally was able to expand her variety store. She hopes to  buy inventory in large quantity for her variety store so that she won't need to frequently go to the market  to purchase supplies.. Therefore she is requesting a loan for additional capital amounting to PHP 11,000.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her general store

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Tinuke

texts.en: Tinu is a cheerful and hardworking young woman. She sells cosmetics and drinks, and wishes to expand her business. She dreams of owning a large store in future. Tinu requesting a loan to purchase more cosmetics and drinks for her business. Tinu is 34-years old and married. She says thank you to kiva lenders, and she looks forward to working towards her dream.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics and drinks to sell

loans.name: Scholasticah

texts.en:
Scholasticah O. recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya.

As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin-enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

Scholasticah has been selling ladies’ shoes, handbags, and new clothing since January 2007. Before starting her own business, Scholasticah was a housewife, caring for her son. She decided to start a business in order to cater to his and her future children’s needs. Scholasticah now also has a 9-month-old daughter.

She sells her items from a stall in downtown Kisumu. The stock comes from different shops in Nairobi in small amounts during monthly trips to the capital.

This will be Scholasticah’s first loan from K-MET. She has applied for a loan of approximately $275 in order to purchase more shoes, handbags, and clothing items.

loans.use: To purchase clothing, shoes, and handbags

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora Bolosos,  age 40, is married with four dependents and is a resident of Laligan, Valencia City. Her husband is only a farm maintenance worker, earning a small income with 3 school aged children to support.  Because of this, Mrs. Bolosos ventured into the grocery retailing business 5 years ago. Fortunately, HSPFI lent her an amount of PHP5000 a initial capital for her business. Today. She wants to make a loan of PHP14,000 to expand her business and meet her customers needs.

Her ambition in life is to expand this business for the benefit of her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery items for resale

loans.name: Bimkubwa

texts.en:
Bimkubwa has been a food seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 4 years. 
She belongs to Hatuchokani loan group (Group code 2094).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $400.Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.  She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.  

Bimkubwa is 34 years old, married, and has one child: aged 2. She also cares for one additional dependant.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Kokadie Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Kokadjè sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent  en majorité dans des  familles traditionnelles polygames à TDJILA situé dans la sous préfecture de NIENA de la 3ème région administrative du Mali. Elles menent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres l’achat - vente de céréales, de canaris,d’arachide.
Elles sont à leur premier prêt (prêt solidaire avec Soro Yiriwaso et  comptent acheter avec ce prêt, 5sacs de 100kg de céréales, 2 sacs de 100 kilogrammes d’arachide et 20 canaris, au marché de KOUGNA,de TIEKOUNKO de BOUGOULABA et de TDJILA. Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de KOUGNA,de TIEKOUNKO de BOUGOULABA et de TDJILA.  en détail au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 5.000FCFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie  investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women in the Kokadjè group are all married and average 33 years of age and 4 children. Most of them live in polygamous traditional families in Tdjila, located in the subprefecture of Niena (third administrative region of Mali). They run diverse businesses, such as, among others : buying and selling cereals, "canaris" (a container used to cook food) and peanuts.

They are seeking their first group loan (solidarity loan) with Kiva's partner Soro Yiriwaso, and intend to use it to buy 5 100-kilogram sacks of cereals, 2 100-kilogram sacks of peanuts, and 20 "canaris" at the Kougna, Tiekounko, Bougoulaba and Tdjila markets. The goods are sold in the same markets, for cash and on credit, to a clientele comprising men and women. They foresee turning an average monthly profit of XOF 5'000 (ca US$ 10) each, to be in part used to provide for their families, and in part invested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell various items (cereals, peanuts, cookware, ...)

loans.name: Ma.liza

texts.en:
Ma. Liza S. owns a rice farm. She is 52 years old and has six children. She started farming in 1980. She formerly owned a dress shop. She sewed, cut fabrics and made desirable clothes for her clients. She has recently opened a sari-sari store (sundries store) where she gets extra income for her family. Her husband, Alfredo S., is also a farmer. Together, they work hard to raise well their children. Their harvest feeds their family and earns a little income when they sell some of the rice to the villagers.

Ma. Liz is asking for a loan of 10,000 pesos from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers, specifically two bags of urea, plus three sacks of quality rice seeds. She is also considering looking for other possible income areas to help her family more.

Ma. Liza is a cluster chairman of CEVI credit program in her village. She has been in CEVI for more than two years. CEVI helps its clients like Ma. Liza to expand their businesses. Ma. Liza enjoys having access to CEVI credit assistance, trainings and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and seeds for her farm.

loans.name: Fotima

texts.ru: Хакназарова Фотима проживает в городе Турсун-Заде. Возраст 47 лет , замужем и имеет четверых детей. Образование среднее. Муж не работает. Обеспечивать семью ей приходится одной. Она занимается торговлей. Продает овощи и фрукты на дехканском рынке. Занимается бизнесом уже 14 лет. Кредит планирует получить для того, чтобы увеличить товарооборот. Погасить кредит сможет в течение  10 месяцев.
texts.en:
Fotima H. lives in Tursunzade. She is 47 years old and is married with four children. She has a high school diploma. Her husband is unemployed and she is the family's only breadwinner. Fotima sells produce at a peasant market. She has been in this business for 14 years. Fotima is applying for a loan that would allow her to increase cash flow. She would repay the loan within 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Oksana Buranbaeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to increase cash flow

loans.name: Som

texts.en: C., age 55, is a local fisherman and has been fishing for four years. He normally depends on fish in and around Tunle Sap Lake, which is the main place for fish to live. Everyday, he gives his fish to his wife to sell at the market. For other income, his wife usually raises pigs at home. The couple has been married for a long time, but has no child. They family's living conditions are not so good because some part of their house has broken; thus, C. needs to borrow a loan in order to repair their old house. The loan will allow them to have a suitable standard of living.

loans.use: To repair their old house.

loans.name: Raha

texts.en:
Raha has been a seamstress and a juice and phone seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 10 years. 
She belongs to Asaakher loan group (Group code 2017).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $125. Every day she works at her business for 14 hours.  She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can increase her inventory for her business. 
She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, pay school fees for her children and save money for future use.  

Raha is 43 years old, married, and has four children: aged 21, 15, 11 and 8.

loans.use: To increase her inventory.

loans.name: Merit

texts.en:
Merit A. recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya.

As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin-enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

Merit was diagnosed with HIV several years ago. For a time she was sick at home, but when she began to feel better she talked with her friends about how to live with HIV. Her friends recommended that she start a business so that she could keep busy and be active. In 2005 Merit began a business selling chips (french fries) in the Nyalenda neighborhood of Kisumu.

Merit chose chips because her parents used to have a similar business and she grew up knowing how to cook and sell chips profitably. Merit purchases about 10 kilograms of potatoes from the Kibuye Market in Kisumu weekly. On a busy day she can sell about half her stock.

Because she has this business, Merit is able to provide for herself and to eat what she wants. She says she doesn’t need to rely on anyone else.

Merit has applied for her first loan from K-MET, of approximately $275. She plans to use this money towards purchasing a machine to fry the chips. If she has a machine, the chips will cook faster and then Merit will not lose customers to long waiting times. Merit would also like to purchase a fridge so that she can sell cold soda with the chips.

loans.use: To purchase a fryer

loans.name: Koromine Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Koromine sont toutes mariées et ont en moyenne  32 ans et  4 enfants. Tan disque les 2/4 des membres vivent dans des foyers traditionnels avec des coépouses, les autres 2/4 vivent dans les  familles traditionnelles monogames et toutes les quatre résident dans le village de Bankorona situé à 2 km de NIENA dans la sous préfecture du même nom,  dans la 3ème région administrative du Mali. Elles menent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres l’achat - vente d’haricots, de savons et de la viande (grillée, en soupe etc).
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle,  elles ont décidé d’intégrer  le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur  premier prêt (prêt de groupe). 
Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt,  plusieurs  sacs de 100 kilogrammes d’haricots, 5 cartons de savons et 3 chèvres pour avoir de la viande pour des fins de restauration. Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de NIENA et à la maison à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 5.000 FCFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie  investie dans leurs activités.
texts.en:
The four women in the Koromine group are all married and average 32 years of age and 4 children. Two of them live in traditional households with co-spouses, whereas the other two live in monogamous traditional families. They all live in the village of Bankorona, located 2 kilometers from Niema, in the subprefecture of the same name, in the third administrative region of Mali. They run diverse businesses, such as, among others : buying and reselling beans, soaps, and meat (grilled, as soup, etc).

To meet customer demand, they decided to join the loan program of the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, a Kiva's partner, from which they are seeking their first group loan. They intend to use it to buy several 100-kg sacks of beans, 5 boxes of soaps, and 3 goats to have obtain meat for restoration. The goods are sold at the Niena market, and at home, to a clientele comprising men and women. They foresee turning an average monthly profit of XOF 5'000 (ca US$ 10) each, to be in part used to provide for their families, and in part invested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell various items (beans, soap, meet, ...)

loans.name: Vero

texts.en: Vero is 55-years old and married with three children. She lives in Ipaja, Lagos state, Nigeria. Vero sells shoes and clothing materials, a business she has had for a long time. Vero is requesting a loan to expand her inventory which will improve her business opportunities. She says thank you to all kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 43 years old and married with four children. She lives in Lagos state, Nigeria. Mary sells provisions like noodles, detergent, toothpaste, etc. She sells retail to her customers. Mary hopes for a loan to purchase more provisions to sell to her customers. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell.

loans.name: Zuwena

texts.en:
Zuwena  has been a fish (majongoo) seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 1 year. 
She belongs to Tumekinai loan group (Group code 2008).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $70.Every day she works at her business for 10 hours.  She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more fish for her business. 
She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, pay school fees for her children and save money for future use.  

Zuwena is 32 years old, married, and has four children: age 11, 9, 7 and 1.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia S. grows rice for a living. Her husband, Elpedio S., manages their small farm. For 37 years, they have been renting a farm to have food for the family. Lydia is 57 years old and works very hard to raise her three children. She wants to send all her children to college so when they are old they will find better jobs to support their future families.

Lydia is asking for a loan of 10,000 pesos to purchase one quart Agrobond and urea fertilizers. She will also buy quality seeds for a good harvest. She also considers looking for some other business line to augment her income. With her loan, she will be able to help her husband more.

CEVI provides its clients the credit assistance they need. It also provides them with relevant trainings and insurance coverage to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and seeds for the farm

loans.name: Rahela Group

texts.en:
Zakerya is the group leader of the Rahela group. There are four members in this group. All of them would like to receive money for his/her business. 

Rabeya and Rahela want to receive a loan for their tailoring business. They want to buy a new sewing machine for their business. Samera wants to receive a loan for her father to buy the necessary materials for his general store.  Zakreya wants to receive a loan to expand and grow his shoe selling business. 

The group appreciates this loan process in Afghanistan that helps poor people.They especiA. want to thank Kiva lenders and AFSG.

loans.use: They all want to expand and  grow their businesses

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Sabougnouma sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 37ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent en majorité dans les  familles traditionnelles polygames à TDJILA situé dans la sous préfecture de NIENA de la 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles menent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres l’achat – vente de céréales, de condiments alimentaires, de canaris et  la restauration.
Elles sont à leur premier prêt (prêt solidaire) qu’elles comptent utiliser pour acheter, 7sacs de 100kg de céréales, 18 canaris, 200 kilo de grains de Néré pour le soumbala et des condiments alimentaires pour la restauration.
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de NIENA, et de BOUGOULABA. Les marchandises sont vendues aux marchés de NIENA, de BOUGOULABA, et de TDJILA en détail et au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 5 750 FCFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie  investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the group Sabougnouma are all married and average 37 years of age and 4 children. Most of them live in traditional polygamous families in TDJILA, located in NIENA sub-prefecture (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They do a variety of work, including the buying and selling of grain, condiments, and canaris (pottery containers) and the catering of food.

The women are on their first loan (solidarity loan), which they plan on using to buy seven 100-kg sacks of grain, 18 canaris, 200 kg of Néré seeds for making

soumbala, and condiments for preparing meals. Supplies are gotten at the markets of NIENA and BOUGOULABA. The goods are sold at the markets of NIENA, BOUGOULABA, and TDJILA at the retail level and in cash, to customers composed of men and women.

The group members each envision realizing an average profit of 5,750 francs CFA per month that will be used in part for family needs and the rest, for investing in business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Abduqahor

texts.ru: Амиров Абдукахор проживает в городе Яван. Живет в центре города , что рядом с рынком. Там он и работает. Занимается бизнесом. Торгует одеждой и обувью. У него пятеро детей. Но он вдовец и воспитывает детей один. Поэтому он очень много роаботает , для того , чтобы дать детям необходимое. Теперь он планирует увеличить товарооборот  путем получения кредита.Погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Abduqahor A. lives in Yavan. He lives in the city centre, which is next to the market. He also works there. He has his own business. He sells clothes and shoes. Abduqahor is a widower and a single father of five. He works hard in order to give his children everything they need. He would like to increase cash flow by obtaining a loan. He would repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Oksana Buranbaeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to increase cash flow

loans.name: Mwamize

texts.en:
Mwamize has been a chicken seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 1 year. 
She belongs to Tupendane loan group (Group code 2001).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $250. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.  She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more chicken for her business. 
She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, improve her home and save money for future use.  

Mwamize is 33 years old, divorced, and has five children: aged 15, 13, 9, 7 and 1.

loans.use: To buy more chicken for her business.

loans.name: Pik

texts.en: A resident of Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, Mrs. P. is a widow who is looking for a loan of $ 800 to buy a new motorcycle for the family to ride. P. is 49 years old and has three children who are all married; two are living in different houses and one is living in the family home. One son is a domestic building worker, age 18. She is a local cultivator, growing vegetables and has some plowers for sale. She wants to reduce the cost of transportation for the family, and that’s why she is requesting a loan.

loans.use: To buy a new one motorcycle for the family.

loans.name: Minviluz

texts.en:
Minviluz D. is a 53 year old mother of 8 children. She earns a living as a rice grower.

Each day, she and her husband Rene D. go out to their farm to work their rice field. They do not mind the hard labor or the heat of the sun; they want to ensure they will have enough food for their family.

Their family is quite big. They need to double the time they work in order to provide for all of their children. Before they farmed, they raised hogs. Now, they focus their attention on growing rice because it allows them to earn more money.

Minviluz is requesting a loan of Php 10,000 so she can increase her farm's yield. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers, insecticides and quality seeds. She hopes another business line of credit will help to increase the family's income.

CEVI provides their clients not just credit assistance but also training, and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, rice seeds and insecticides

loans.name: Hai Thi

texts.vi: Nguyễn Thị Hải sinh năm 1977, ( mã số: 010117140040). chị bán hàng quần áo tại chợ, có thu nhập theo ngày. Chồng chị làm công nhân có thu nhập ổn định theo tháng. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 3.000.000 vn đ/tháng. Chị tham gia vay mức vốn: 1.508.000 vnd (hoàn trả trong 25 tuần)để đầu tư thêm hàng quần áo. Đây là lần đầu tiên chị tham gia vay vốn, chị thuộc nhóm vay vốn của chị Nguyễn Thị Lanh( trong ảnh chị đứng phía sau mặc áo kẻ ngang. Chị hứa hoàn trả đầy đủ vốn vay để chu kỳ vốn sau tiếp tục tham gia với mức vay cao hơn.
texts.en:
Mrs. Hai Thi N., 32 years old, SEDA ID# 010117140040. She sells clothes in a local market and has daily income. Her husband is a construction worker and has stable monthly income. The family’s income is about 3,000,000 VND per month. She wants to borrow 1,508,000 VND( term of 25 weeks) to buy clothes inventory. This is her first time borrowing money. She is in a group led by Mrs. Lanh Thi N.( the one with striped shirt). She plans to pay the loan on time to continue working with the SEDA fund.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy clothes inventory

loans.name: Tuzinduke Group

texts.en:
Raya  has owned a small charcoal store and has been a perfume seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 2 years. 
She currently earns an average monthly profit of $50. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.  She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal and perfume for her business. 
She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, improve her home and save money for future use.  

Raya is 22 years old, single. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Halima. Who also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal  and perfume for her business.

loans.name: Badenya Group

texts.fr:
Les six femmes du groupe Badenya sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans et  5 enfants. Une seule femme vit dans une  famille polygame et les autres dans des familles nucléaires au quartier Sanoubougou I de la ville de Sikasso, une préfecture de la 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
 Elles menent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres l’achat – vente de la friperie, des tissus, de fruits et  la restauration.
Elles collaborent  avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Elles sont à leur premier prêt (prêt solidaire)
Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt, une balle de friperie, 2 rouleaux de tissus, des oranges et quelques condiments pour la restauration.
 Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Sikasso, dans les foires hebdomadaires des villages environnants, à Bamako et à Bobo Dioulasso  au BURKINA FASO.
Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de Sikasso et dans les foires hebdomadaires de la localité en gros et en détail; et souvent à crédit et au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 14.170 FCFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie  investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The six women in the Badenya group are all married and average 39 years of age and 5 children. One woman lives in a polygamous family, while the others live in nuclear families in the Sanoubougou I neighborhood in Sikasso, a prefecture in the third administrative region of Mali.

They run diverse businesses, among others : buying and reselling second-hand clothing, fabrics or fruits, and food serving. To meet customer demand, they work with the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso, a Kiva's partner. They are seeking their first group loan (solidarity loan). With this loan, they intend to buy one bale of second-hand clothing, two rolls of fabric, oranges, and condiments for food preparation.

They get their supplies at the Sikasso market, at the weekly fairs held in the surrounding villages, in Bamako, and in Bobo Dioulasso in Burkina Faso. The goods are sold, retail and wholesale, at the Sikasso market and at the weekly fair in Sikasso. They sell for cash or on credit, to a clientele composed of men and women.

They intend to turn a monthly profit of XOF 14'170 (ca US$ 30) each, to be used partly for the family expenses, and partly to invest in their businesses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell second-hand clothing, fabrics, fruits and condiments

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy is 28 years old and married without children. She lives in Lagos state, Nigeria. Her husband is a commercial driver. Joy sells provisions and cosmetics, something she has done for a long time. Joy hopes for a loan to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell.

loans.name: Nia Njema Group

texts.en:
Salamuu has been a clothes seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 1 year.  
She currently earns an average monthly profit of $90. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.  She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes for her business. 
She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.  

Salamuu is 24 years old, married, and has two children: aged 5 and 11 months. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Asia and Bahati. Each woman also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity is 30 years old and she is married with three children. Her husband is a pastor. Charity sells foodstuffs and school sandals. Charity is requesting a loan to purchase more foodstuffs in large quantities to sell to her customers. She hopes to expand her business and make more profit. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Salma has been a snacks seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 3 years. 
She belongs to Faraja loan group (Group code 2059).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $65. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.  She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items for her business. 
She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.  

Salma is 38 years old, divorced, and has four children: aged 22, 12, 5 and 2. She also cares for one additional dependant.

loans.use: To buy more items for the expansion of her business.

loans.name: Success

texts.en: Success is 35 years old and married with three children. Success sells foodstuffs retail to her customers. Success needs a loan to purchase more foodstuffs in large quantities to sell. She hopes to expand her business. She is a LAPO client. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Tumejidhatiti Group

texts.en:
Riziki J. has been a soup seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 1 year. 
She currently earns an average monthly profit of $35. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.  She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items for her business. 
She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.  

Riziki J. is 45 years old, married, and has six children: aged 19, 17,16,14, 11 and 9. 
She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Riziki S. and Sikudhani. Each woman also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To expand her business (To buy more items for her business.)

loans.name: Eveline

texts.en:
Eveline O. recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya.

As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin-enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

Eveline decided to work with K-MET because, she says, it is a good community network and the organization can help the community grow.

Eveline is 36 years old, has been married for 25 years, and is the mother of a 17-year-old daughter who currently attends form 3 in secondary school.

In 2004 Eveline went from being a housewife to a small business owner. She began thinking, “If I can sell chapatti, I can help my child.” As an accomplished cook, Eveline knew that she could make chapatti (a soft flat bread) that would sell. The business started that year and Eveline has been successfully selling chapatti over the last 5 years.

She has applied for her first loan from K-MET, requesting approximately $150 in order to purchase paraffin and flour.

loans.use: To purchase paraffin and flour

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria is 27 years old and married with a child. She sells clothing material used by Nigerian women to make native blouses and wraps (clothes that are tied around the waist and also used to carry babies on the back). She has been in this business for a long time. She also sells women's footwear. Gloria hopes for a loan to purchase more clothing material to sell. She hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing material to sell.

loans.name: Pik

texts.en: Mrs. P. is 35 years old and her husband's name is Ruon, aged 31. They currently live in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. P. raises oxen for its offspring, and she also uses them for her rice farming business. Her husband is a local construction worker, and they are currently earning approximately $5 each day. The couple now cares for three children, all of them are still young and are enrolled in primary school. P. and her husband work hard at the business everyday for daily income to make sure their children receive the highest education. P. has requested a loan to buy a second-hand motorcycle for the family's riding needs.

loans.use: To buy a second-hand motorcycle for the family.

loans.name: Usuhbayar

texts.en: Usuhbayar N. is a 41-year-old woman who lives with her husband and three children. Her eldest is a 20-year-old girl who works at a tourist camp. She also has a 19-year-old boy, currently unemployed. Usuhbayar's youngest child goes to elementary school. She has been running her business since 1990. When she began running her business, she cobbled traditional Mongolian shoes and her husband sold them. Since 1996, she has run a clothing business with her husband. They rent a clothing stall at the "Herlen" market in Baganuur city. Once a month, one of them goes to Ereen, a city just across the Chinese border, to buy variety of women's clothes, including blouses, skirts and sweaters. The loan they are asking for now is to buy a variety of clothes to increase their business inventory. With her husband, Usuhbayar is building a garage in her yard; however, they don't have a vehicle yet. She says, "Our destiny is in our hands. So my family would like to have our own car. We'll work for that."

loans.use: To buy a variety of clothes

loans.name: Kate

texts.en: Kate is a cheerful and jovial woman. She is a hair stylist and has been in this business for a long time. She needs a loan to purchase one hair dryer and hair styling creams. Kate is a mother of four, is 35 years old, and married. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase one hair dryer and styling creams.

loans.name: Saidat

texts.en: Saidat says that hair styling is now a part of her. After her two years of training, she finally started her own beauty salon. She also sells hair extensions, styling creams, etc. She hopes for a loan to purchase a generator set to supplement her electricity. She does not want to lose her customers to competitors. Saidat is 30 years old and married with a child.

loans.use: To purchase a generator set.

loans.name: Munhbat

texts.en: Munhbat L. is a 28-year-old man who lives with his wife and two daughters. His daughters are two and three years old; both go to kindergarten. Munhbat's family moved to Baganuur city from Baruun Baidlag soum (a soum is a small municipality) in 2008. Before his family moved to Baganuur city, he was a herder who took care of over 100 animals, mostly sheep and goats. However, he wanted to live in the city; therefore, he sold all his livestock to buy a pick-up truck to start a transport business. Now he transports all sorts of loads, picking up and dropping off grocery store goods, moving furniture, etc. Sometimes he purchases coal from the local coal mine, bags it, and sells it out of his truck (most Mongolians who live in the traditional nomad's "ger" heat their homes with coal against the frigid winter nights). This pick-up truck is the family's only source of income. He is requesting a loan to buy tires and other supplies for his truck. One day, he wants to build his own house in his yard. His family is now living in the local ger district (a ger district is where many people have settled in nomadic homes, forming a sort of ad hoc suburb). Munhbat is pictured with his wife.

loans.use: To buy tires and other supplies for his truck

loans.name: May

texts.en: Mr. M. is 38 years old a resident of Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. He has been operating a workshop next to his house for along time, providing a service for repairing motorbikes and bicycles. He currently makes an income of $4 per day to support his family's daily expense. M. is married to Pheap, 22, who is a good house wife and who makes a living planting a little vegetable patch on her own farmland. M. is asking for a loan to buy more motorcycle accessories to fulfill his customers' needs.

loans.use: To buy more motorcycle accessories for his repair shop.

loans.name: Hoja

texts.ru: Одилов Ходжа житель города Яван. Живет он в одном из отдаленных кишлаков города. Зарабатывает на жизнь путем разведения крупно рогатого скота. Занимается этим делом уже шесть лет. Ему 46 лет , он женат и имеет шестерых детей. Обратился за кредитом для того, чтобы купить дойную корову. Получаемое молоко сможет продавать и таким образом получать дополнительный доход. Погасить кредит планирует в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Hoja O. lives in one of the most remote villages of Yavan. He makes a living by raising livestock. He has been in this business for 6 years. Hoja is 46 years olf and is married with six children. He would like to get a loan so that he could purchase a dairy cow and make extra cash by selling milk. Hoja would be able to repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Oksana Buranbaeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Istemeli

texts.en: Istemeli A. is a 35-year-old farmer who breeds calves in the small village of Imishli City. Istemeli is married and has one son. He has been involved in this business since his childhood, thanks to his father who passed to him the best experience in looking after animals. Istemeli has a car, which he uses to take local people from one village to another. Cattle breeding is the main financial source for his family. Istemeli would like to expand his business and purchase two more calves.

loans.use: Purchase two calves.

loans.name: Nakhida

texts.en: Nakhida A. is a 40-year-old married woman with one son. She has been involved in the cattle breeding ever since she got married. She likes look after the calves and does it with a great pleasure because this business is the main financial source for her family. Since she is a housewife, she enjoys having her own business and would like to expand her business via purchasing two more calves. For this purpose she applied for $1200.

loans.use: Purchase two calves.

loans.name: Sanobar

texts.en: Sanobar is an enterprising mother looking to make a better future for the well being of her 5 children, which motivates her to work day to day in the cultivation of crops such as: wheat, potatoes, onions, and watermelons. Sanobar tends to her business with great care and dedication. Her sister helps her with the business as well. They sell their products at the local market. Sanobar is one of the better sellers but what keeps her back is her limited product range. In order to sell more, she needs to grow more on her land. This is the reason why Sanobar is asking for a loan, and she expects that it will help her to increase her business and, above all, give her the purchasing power to meet the needs of her family.

loans.use: Purchasing of the seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Izakhat

texts.en: Izakhat M. is a 57-year-old trader who sells different kinds of food products. In his own shop he sells a wide range of candies, cookies and yogurts. Izakhat is married with five children. His big family helps him in his business and sometimes replaces him while he make some money on the side as a driver. He often takes local people from his village to another, which brings him additional income. But his main income is still his food shop. Izakhat applied for $1200 to purchase more food products for his shop to increase his income.

loans.use: Purchase food products to resell

loans.name: Kabirat

texts.en: Kabirat styles hair for her customers. She also sells children’s clothes. She needs a loan to purchase one hair dryer and styling creams. She is a LAPO client. Kabirat is 37 years old and married with two children. She says thank you to Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase one hair dryer and styling creams.

loans.name: Kamala

texts.en: Kamala N. is a 47-year-old woman who breeds calves for meat to sell. Kamala is married and has one daughter, and they live with her husband's parents all in one house. Kamala has experience in this business for more than 20 years. This business is the main source of income in her family. Kamala also works as a teacher in the local school. Kamala applied for $1200 to purchase two more calves for breeding.

loans.use: Purchase two calves

loans.name: Kang

texts.en: Mrs. P. is 37 years old and a resident of Siem Reap Province where she owns a plot of land in her village, growing corn for sale. She is a mother of three children; they are all still young and under her care. Her husband is a local building worker. P. is widely known in her business of domestic corn growing, in which she plants four time a year. She works hard at her business activities every day and never wastes time. Corn growing is P.'s main source of income and provides her and her family with enough food. Recently, P.’s family has faced a problem with transportation because of the cost of paying a motor taxi driver. To reduce the cost of transportation, P. has requested a loan of $400 to buy a motorbike for family traveling.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for family traveling.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen sells foodstuffs and she has been in this business for a long time. Helen sells retail to customers. She wants to purchase foodstuffs in large quantities to enable her to meet the demands of her customers. She hopes for a loan  to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. Helen is 41 years old and married with three children. She is indeed grateful to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Rakhila

texts.en: Rakhila B. is a 53-year-old teacher who breeds calves for meat production in the small village of Imishli City. She is married and has three children who are studying at the university and at school. Rakhila needs $1200 to purchase two calves to improve the life conditions of her family. She will be grateful for your help.

loans.use: Purchase two calves

loans.name: Bakhruz

texts.en: Bakhruz A. is a young man of 26, married with 2 children. Bakhruz keeps a food store in the small village of Imishli City where he sells macaroni, preserved food, tea, sugar and other items. Bakhruz got this shop from his father and continued this business. His main profession is photographer, and sometimes he works in the local wedding parties. His family income depends on the shop that Bakhruz keeps. Now he would like to expand his business and purchase more food products for his store.

loans.use: Purchase food products to resell

loans.name: Komiljon

texts.en:
Komiljon is a hard-working man who goes to cultivate his fields every morning with great care. He also tends to his calves, taking them to feed in the mornings. His work demonstrates his dedication to his cows, because one way or another they contribute to his household expenses. Early in the morning his wife milks them and sells it nearby. Most recently, Komiljon has wanted to invest in purchasing another cow so that his wife can sell more milk in the cities, which will help his business to continue growing economically. He is requesting a loan of 2000 Somoni for these purposes.


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 
But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing small cattle for developing business

loans.name: Chab

texts.en: C., 60, owns a medium dump truck for a transporting service for soil and firewood. He lives in Siem Reap Province and has 8 children; three of them are single and under his care and the other are married and live separately. He is married to Sor, 37, who is a local firewood seller. C. is running the business very well and he has a skill for attracting customers to his service. Unfortunately, C. can't provide his goods service as before because his truck has broken frequently. Therefore, he is asking for a loan of $1000 to repair his broken truck.

loans.use: To repair his broken truck he uses for his transporting business.

loans.name: Elchin

texts.en: Elchin K. is a 22-year-old man who sells different goods such as food, home products and toothpaste. He started his business three years ago when hunger knocked at his door. Elchin decided not to enter the university, and he started his own business. He borrowed some money from his relatives and opened a small shop share he started to sell foodstuffs such as macaroni, sugar and salt. After two years he expanded his business and started selling other items such as home products and bath items. Now Elchin would like to expand his store and purchase more foodstuffs for his store to improve his family life conditions. Elchin and his family count on your help.

loans.use: Purchase food products

loans.name: Bakhtiyor

texts.en:
Bakhtiyor Y. is 27 years old. He is married and the father of 3 children. Bakhtiyor is an optimistic, hardworking father. He works his land with love and dedication every day, so that it produces excellent vegetables. He also raises cattle.

Bakhtiyor has been working the land for two years. He learned this skill from his beloved father (pictured) who takes care of his land when Bakhtiyor travels to the market to sell his produce and cattle. His loving wife is also involved in the family business, as you can see in the photo.

Though growing vegetables is a very difficult and timetaking job, he hopes to gather a rich harvest. He is planning to fix his house and save money to support his family. He is requesting a loan of 2000 Somoni. Bakhtiyor thanks your generous hearts for a swift contribution.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Oikhol

texts.en:
Y. Oikhol is a farmer and believes that working in fields brings her a lot of satisfaction. For more than three years, she and her husband have been living off of their agricultural profits and efforts. Yakuboya currently grows a wide range of vegetables, including carrot, potato, and tomato which she sells to earn a stable income. Yakuboya works hard in order to provide her children with the necessary education they need to survive. She believes that her children’s future and success is critical in achieving their dreams.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing farming tools and fertilizer to increase profits

loans.name: Sinjiya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Sinjiya sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent en majorité dans des familles monogames dans le quartier Sanoubougou I de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. ).
 Elles menent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres l’achat – vente de la friperie, des tissus, du bois de chauffe,des condiments alimentaires, de l’encens et de la restauration.
Elles sont à leur premier prêt (prêt solidaire) et comptent  l’utiliser pour acheter,  une ½ balle de friperie, 1 chargement de véhicule de 10 tonnes en bois de chauffe, des ingrédients pour l’encens (parfum magnon kisèni et gueni) et des condiments alimentaires. Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Sikasso, dans les foires hebdomadaires des villages environnants, à Bamako et Bobo Dioulasso au BURKINA FASO. Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de Sikasso et dans les foires hebdomadaires des villages,  au comptant  en détail  et souvent à crédit  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 15.670FCFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie  investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women in the Sinjiya group are all married and average 33 years of age and 4 children. Most of them live in monogamous families in the Sanoubougou I neighborhood in the city of Sikasso, third administrative region of Mali. They run diverse businesses, which are, among others, buying and selling second-hand clothing, fabrics, firewood, food condiments, frankincense, as well as food serving.

They are seeking their first group loan (solidarity loan) and intend to use it to buy half a bale of second-hand clothing, one 10-ton truckload of firewood, ingredients for frankincense (magnon kisèni and gueni perfumes) and food condiments. The get their supplies at the market in Sikasso, at the weekly fairs in the surrounding villages, in Bamako and in Bobo Dioulasso in Burkina Faso. The goods are sold at the Sikasso market and at the weekly fairs in the villages, for cash or on credit, to a clientele comprising men and women.

They intend to turn a monthly profit of XOF 15'670 (ca US$ 31) to be used partly to pay family expenses, and partly to be invested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell second-hand clothing, firewood and food condiments

loans.name: Oladunni

texts.en: Oladunni is 43 years old and married with 3 children. Her husband is a journalist. She sells provisions, drinks, and bottled water by retail. She hopes for a loan to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thank you to Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell.

loans.name: Sherifattu

texts.en: Sherifattu B. sells wine and juice by wholesale and retail to her customers. She has been in this business for a long time. She loves this business because she makes lots of profit. She needs a loan to purchase more cartons of wine and juice to sell. She is 53 years old and married with four children. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more cartons of wine and juice to sell.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Ms. G. is 30 years old and not married.  She is a hairdresser and her salon is located in the Kennedy neighborhood of the city of Caacupé.  She has been working as a hairdresser for more than 12 years, and now she has a permanent clientele, made up especially of the area’s civil servants, who always come to her salon to request manicures, pedicures, hair coloring, and hair cuts.  

She says that her greatest achievement was to have located her salon in an area with many people and to equip it with the necessary equipment to provide the services that are in the highest demand.  This enabled her to grow her clientele and make herself well-known in the neighborhood. 

Ms. G. has a related project to augment her business with the purchase of display cabinets where she would be able to sell jewelry and beauty products, among other things. 

With the loans she receives from Fundación Paraguaya she can buy furniture and some accessories for her hair salon.

loans.use: Supplies such as hair dyes, creams, shampoos, and furniture for the salon

loans.name: Von

texts.en: O. is a single women, 24 years old, and a resident of Siem Reap Province where she earns a living by working as a domestic construction worker. She currently lives with her father who helps supporting the family by planting local vegetables. O. is facing the problem that when she goes to work, she always has to pay a taxi. To reduce the cost of transportation, she would like to ask for a $350 loan to buy a second-hand motorcycle for riding to work. (O.'s father is pictured because she was not available that day.)

loans.use: To buy a second-hand motorcycle for riding to work.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary B. is married and has 3 children. She has received schooling through junior high. Mary sells cosmetics and bags of salt, which she has done since 2000. Her husband is a nurse. Mary uses her income to pay for house keeping expenses. Mary will use the loan to purchase more cosmetics and bags of salt to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to develop a plot of land which she bought with her husband to pay for their house.

loans.use: Mary will use the loan to purchase more cosmetics and bags of salt to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Khijran

texts.en: Khijran J. is a 46-year-old woman whose main source of income is bread making. Khijran is married with five children. Khijran's mother taught her how to make bread, and she chose it for the main business in her life of housewife. Early in the morning Khijran wakes up to make pastry and at 9 a.m. she starts to make bread in the big oven that she has in her own yard. She sells bread to the local people and to the restaurants. This is a very profitable business, but to make this business more successful, Khijran needs to build a better oven to speed up the whole process of bread making. For this purpose she applied for $1200. Let’s do our best to help this hard-working woman.

loans.use: Purchase products for the process of bread making.

loans.name: Yodgorboy

texts.en:
Yodgorboy A. is 31 years old. He lives in Isfara town. He is married and has two children. Yodgorboy processes and sells dried fruits in the central market. He is experienced in the business of processing dried fruits. He purchases dried fruits from local farmers wholesale and after processing, sells them to his customers. Because he buys his goods wholesale, his prices are lower than regular market prices.

Yodgorboy offers a wide assortment of goods for customers of different means. This allows Yodgorboy to make his business quite successful and it brings in a stable income for the family. Currently, he needs a loan of 550 USD to buy supplies so he can continue to offer a good product to his customers. Yodgorboy expresses his gratitude for everyone supporting him.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Increasing his range of goods

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en: Georgina A. is married and has four dependents. She has received schooling through commercial college and now sells food supplies like groundnuts at the Elmina New Market, which she has done since 1996. Her husband works as a commercial driver. Georgina uses her income to pay for housekeeping expenses and will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of food supplies to meet the increased demand of her customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Georgina plans to develop a plot of land which she bought with her husband to build their family house.

loans.use: To purchase more food to resell to customers

loans.name: Dilshod

texts.en:
Dilshod A. is 27 years old and is married. His wife stays at home but is currently training to be a hairdresser. She wants to open a salon so that she can supplement her husband’s income. Dilshod sells hay for animals at his house and at the market. He buys the hay wholesale from local farmers. Having been working on this business for 9 years already, he has become a well-known seller of hay in his village and has many customers who buy hay only from him. The price he charges for hay is based on the quantity that his customer buys.

Dilshod also offers a discount to his regular buyers, to those customers who come to him often. With a loan from IMON International, Dilshod plans to increase his stock in order to fully meet the demand of his growing customer base. He says that the demand is there and his problem is being able to supply enough hay. The well-being of this young family is in your hands.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: buying more hay for re-sale

loans.name: Eniola

texts.en: Eniola is 36 years old and married with two children. She owns a video club where she rents out videos, and she also sells rechargeable phone cards. She has been in this business for a long time. Eniola needs a loan to purchase more videos and rechargeable phone cards to sell. Eniola is a LAPO client. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more videos and rechargeable phone cards

loans.name: Adelakun

texts.en:
Adelakun S. runs a beautfy salon. In her salon, she also has a deep freezer, from which she sells drinks to her cutomers.

She gives her customers lovely hair styles.

Adelakun S. now needs a loan of N100,000 to purchase two hair dryers for her salon. She would also like to purchase crates for the drinks that she sells.

She is 32 years old and married with 2 children. She hopes to expand her business and increase her profits. She says thanks to all kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase two hair dryers and crates of drinks for her beauty salon

loans.name: Rasim

texts.en: Rasim F. is a 39-year-old baker, married with five children. Rasim started his business two years ago, and before he was working as a baker in a local factory in his village. But in 2006 he decided to open a small bakery in his house. With saved money, he purchased a special pastry-making machine. This machine is old and Rasim applied for $1200 to purchase a modern pastry-making machine. He believes this will make bread-making easier and faster.

loans.use: Purchase a special pastry-making machine.

loans.name: Teodocia

texts.en:
Mrs. Teodocia B. is 38 years old and she is married with two children. She has a small store and meat shop which she runs from her home, a business she has had for more than 12 years. Her main customers are workers in the area, as well as tourists who come to the city to visit the rivers in the area. She also gets customers from the weekend craft expo that is held in the plaza in the city.

At this time, she plans to expand her business for the summer and she is already doing so. She is constructing an area where she will sell fast food and snacks, cold drinks, fruit salads, and ice cream.

Mrs. B. says that she does very good business on the weekends and during the middle of the day during the week. Thanks to this business, she is able to support her family and help her husband to cover the household’s costs.

With the loans she receives from Fundación Paraguaya, she is able to purchase all types of goods for her store, like drinks, meat, milk, oil, rice, flour, eggs, etc.

loans.use: Products for the store such as rice, milk, flour, eggs, beverages, meat, oil, etc.

loans.name: Gulnoz

texts.en:
Gulnoz A. is a 41 year old woman. She is married and the mother of five children.  Aside from caring for her family and her home, Gulnoz has a grocery store which she attends to herself. She began her small business 8 years ago with financial support from her husband who is a farmer. The reason for starting the business was to increase her large family’s income.  The business has been gradually growing ever since.  From the profit from her business Gulnoz was able to arrange the wedding of her two elder sons and is  planning to educate the rest of her children and to arrange their weddings too. In order to expand her business she requests for a loan of $ 800 US dollars. Gulnoz is planning to use the loan to purchase a more diverse range of goods to sell. She promises to repay her loan within 6 months and thanks everybody who decides to support her.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key place along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 
But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To increase the diversity of goods  for selling

loans.name: Saida

texts.en:
Saida A. is 19 years old. She is living with her parents. Two years ago her father bought tailoring machine for her and since than she has been providing tailoring services in her house. Before then, she worked at tailoring shop and there she learned the skills necessary for a successful business. Saida now has a well-established clientele, the majority of whom are young girls who often order the national dresses. In this way, she constantly adds new clients and has seen her business grow. She is requesting a loan of $ 500 USD for the term of 9 months to purchase a new modern tailoring machine for sewing dresses. Saida and her family are grateful for your generosity and support.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key place along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and the birthplace of the great Persian poet Rudaki and the most famous Islamic philosopher Ibn Sina (Avicenna). The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, and Central Asian traditions. 
But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase a new modern tailoring machine for sewing dresses.

loans.name: Mamurjon

texts.en:
Mamurjon is a 32-year-old young man with a wife and three children. He dedicates his time to driving a taxi and a microbus. He currently relies on the two vehicles for his public transport business, one of which he drives personally. He rents the microbus.  Mamurjon has about two years of experience in the public transportation field. The competition is rather high in this business since there are so many people who need it. He is requesting a loan of  600 USD for the term of 6 months. His  request is so that he can maintain his vehicles. With the loan he’ll purchase  spare parts for his microbus. With your support, Mamurjon will continue to progress. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International
